reviewText:
EDIT 8/11/2015: The second update released in October 29th brings not only improved graphics, better car combat and more tweaks, but also additional performance improvements. Fully playable at max settings for me. Props to the dev team for taking care of the issues that the game had at launch!

Carmageddon Reincarnation is a return to a classic series of games that were only about free-roaming fun, splatter and top notch physics (back in the days). If you liked the old Carmageddon games, you will certainly like this one, probably even more; it still has that PlayStation 1 era" feeling (warning: may cause nostalgia).
If you are new to Carmageddon
date:
don't expect realistic driving and "next-gen" graphics (or you'll end up like the majority of the community who expected "changes" to a remake) but prepare for internal organs and in-your-face destruction with power-ups and aggressive car combat.

PROS+ A true Carmageddon game
+ Free-roaming
recommended: detailed maps\n+ Along with classic carma gameplay
hoursPlayed:
new gamemodes are introduced
+ Challenging AI and Multiplayer mode
+ The soundtrack

CONS- Handling can be occasionally frustrating
- No peds in multiplayer (yet)
- Minor AI problems
- Not many cars to choose from
- Lacks optimization and suffers from a few crashes to desktop.
- Very long loading times

Personal rating: 8/10 (Erased with the Aug. 2015 patch)"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

:Update at end:
I'll be honest straight off the bat...

I got this because I wanted 1/2 without having to dig out all my old disks then struggle with the Nosebleed packs once again, so I'm classing this as the freebie in my buy (C:1 Max, C:2, C:TDR2k were my wants)

Yet 2 hours in, and I am yearning for more, It FEELS like Carmageddon, The one thing that worried me most would be the old games would be lost in a new 'Vision' yet besides the UI quirks and a few missing bits and bobs... It is without a doubt, Carmageddon!

There is a lot of talk about performance and what not, and Sure, it's a bit sluggish at times (i7 3770k(stock), GTX 660ti, Soundblaster Z and 8Gig RAM on an x77 AsRock) but does that detract from the fun in a game like Carmageddon this early in its lifespan? I'm normally a stickler for stuttering and tearing and the like, yet after 5~ mins on a track, I only seem to notice the biggest of slow downs and hitches, Peds still have all the charm of the old games so far and the familiar audio queue's are a treat to any fan of the series, They may be more of an issue in a MP scenario but thats not How I Carma".

The few tracks/Routes in the game so far (Should change with luck tomorrow
date: Happy Valentine!) are what we've come to expect from a Carma game

reviewText:
NEW UPDATE!This new update brings some fixes for people with specific issues (dual-cores crashing, etc), support for vehicles with more than 4 wheels for modders (and the Suppressor is probably coming in a future update, now that the tech works) and... vehicle tracks!

This is probably the highlight of the update:
The Blitzkrieg (renamed King Merc, due to legal issues) is an awesome vehicle, I think it's my favorite now!
The track tech behind it is impressive to say the least, you get to see all the details on the moving tracks, the springs, and how it adapts when it loses gears/wheels is awesome, way more than I can understand. It was well worth the wait, they didn't spare any details.

There's also another vehicle, the Shredlight, which seems to have a pretty nice handling, although I haven't played much with it.
Didn't try multiplayer yet, but there were some balance changes so hopefully it is more enjoyable now!

Performance remains roughly the same, on my rig at least.

Can't wait for all the stuff coming next year!



Old update:I can only recommend this game even more with the latest patch!

Visuals have improved by a good bit, especially on vehicles and overall atmosphere. Game looks quite sexy as long as you have a decent rig.

There were also performance improvements but I don't have anything to say about that as I did upgrade my computer, so I don't have a reliable comparison between the latest patch and the previous one.
I can, however, say that the game runs pretty well, all options maxed out at 1080p (left vsync off for obvious reasons), without the slightest hint of stutters on the following hardware:

Resumed Specs:Intel i7 6700K
16GB RAM
GTX 970 Gaming G1
Samsung 850 EVO SSD 250GB



Old review below:
I've owned the game for a while now, as a paypal backer, and I can finally recommend it to everyone, even for those who have average systems.

The gameplay has always been good and is a welcome improvement over their first two games, with welcome additions. Definitely a lot of fun, thumbs up!(let's skip the black sheep of the family, TDR2000, since it was not made by Stainless Games)

After the last update, it indeed runs much, much better than it did, and is perfectly playable without annoying low performance issues (such as stuttering, stalling, and overall low FPS).

Pros:Play your own way on this fun gameplay, based on the first two games. Either race like a pleb, wreck your opponents or go after these on-foot running ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•s. Has a few extra gamemodes that were not seen in any of the previous Carmageddon games.
Unique levels, no other 'racing' game has this much vertical creativity going on.
Incredible damage technology, twist and wreck your car like no other game.
Crazy selection of vehicles, nothing like wrecking some supercars and sports cars with your big ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• plowing industrial machine. You have pickups, jet powered cars, dragsters, off-road SUVs, lowriders, industrial machines, sports and race cars, monster trucks, buggies, even a killin' hearse. And then you got the cops.
Peds. Nothing like running over these little ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• and watching the blood splash everywhere.
Good soundtrack. Not the most varied (3 artists, this is an indie game after all), but I think it fits the game well.
Lots of powerups to use and abuse.
It's Carmageddon.
Cons:Some of the engine sounds are underwhelming, especially sports cars.
Some vehicles need a bit more balancing on their handling side.
Not a game issue, but some people are too lazy to wait on a multiplayer lobby, leaving it quickly instead of waiting a minute or two to get more people to join. If everyone leaves, then of course we can't start a session!
While it's not perfect (no game is), it no longer has major performance issues, which was the only real issue I had with it.

I have to say, some people here on the Steam reviews really exaggerated the issues it used to have, the game didn't run nearly as bad as some of these reviews say.
Probably because some of these not-so-bright guys were complaining about the game not running on their so called fancy i7 laptop with an integrated GPU. Just because you got ripped off on a crappy laptop and scream of buyers remorse, it doesn't mean it's the games fault that it runs slowly.


Resumed Specs:i3 540 @ 4.21Ghz (it's still a slow CPU)
8GB RAM
GTX 460 1GB (that was considered a mid range GPU back in 2010/2011, for all you whiners out there)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has brough tears to my eyes. If I was a child subjected to the adversities of cancer and I had a make-a-wish, it would be for the remake of Carmageddon in a glorified, gorified, monstrous, blood-strocity of carkilling, ped-pulverizing action and I would probably be the happiest person in the galaxy to have had a game related wish come true!

Seriously. This game is stupendous. The nostalgia is incredible. My boner won't go away and these days that is really difficult to even give me one without feeling dirty. This is the first boner i've ever had for a game that I was not ashamed of. IF you happen to be the generation that is unfamiliar with the Carmageddon series, think twisted metal except more destruction, more blood, more powerups, more satisfaction. Think Iron Maiden. Think about selling your first born for happiness. Think about becoming the opposite gender for a day and doing everything that you ever wanted.

Think about Carmageddon. It is worth it. It is glorious. It is a trophy in the library. It is magic.

100/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Nostalgia and AWESOME have just made a baby, and its name is Carmageddon: ReinCarnation!

The game still has a long way to go, but it already lives up to my expectations! If you don't like unfinished products and crashing games, don't buy it just yet. They still have a long way to go. But if you're a heavy Carmageddon fan, and you want to see the game progressing from pre-alpha to alpha to beta and eventually to the final product, then this is for you. You might even get to stuff some ideas in the developers head, or you may find some game breaking bugs, so they can finish this game as good as possible. Carmageddon is back people!
voteText: 34 of 42 people (81%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off, I cannot recommend this game enough. If you were a fan of the original Carmageddon, then you will instantly feel right at home playing Reincarnation. The developers have managed to bring back the original thrill of the first game, coupled with the gameplay updates from Carpocolypse Now, without the bad aftertaste of TDR 2000.

If you are not familiar with the Carmageddon series, then you have a gaping hole in your gaming history. Basically, its a ridiculous, fast-paced, balls-to-the-wall race, except you can take out the other racers with impunity and destroy some oblivious pedestrians along the way. Although the races have specific courses to follow, each takes place in an open-environment, allowing the driver to go anywhere the vehicle can fit.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is now at a point that it can be recommended. It's still got some polishing to do, and there is the odd bug, but in the last 3 hours I've had zero crashes and very playable framerates on med/high settings (R9 270X).

As for the gameplay, I think the highest compliment that can be paid is to say that this *is* the Carmageddon you've been waiting for.

[Pre Alpha] 18/06/2014

So here it is, a new Carmageddon game. If you were one of the origonal carma players as i was then you will probably have fond memories of old ladies (or zombies before splat pack came out) flying up and down your windscreen as you pull off that Cunting Stunting" bonus. You will also likely remember the countless reiterations of the game such as TDR 2000
date: dont let these other carma titles put you off AT ALL ! Carma's back baby
recommended:
and its better than ever.

The Good:

- New "soft body" technology allows for cars to be crushed and crumpled like never before.
- Driver (Max Damage) flys out of the car on high impacts resulting in funny (gore filled) crashes. (No Die Anna at present)
- Hugh attention to detail i.e when repairing your car

- Padestrians are back and there more 'squishy' than ever !

- Good physics and car handling

reviewText: Gotta give the devs credit. While it could be said that the game should have been released in a finished state to begin with, it's still good to see them enthusiastically updating the game constantly, despite the less than stellar reviews. After the second, 7 GB update, the game is finally what it should have been on release. voteText: 33 of 44 people (75%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I loved Carma back in the 90's and I was a backer on this one. So I've been following development on the game, since day one. And I can't say that I'm blown away by the final release, as it has a few technical issues. For the most part, the framerate is quite inconsistent - though turning off V-sync or running D3DOverrider, seems to help a bit with that particular issue.

Technical issues do hamper the overrall experience, but there is fun to be had here. It's pretty much Carmageddon, as you remember it, in a shiny new package, with a  couple of added game modes and power-ups. So if you never liked Carmageddon to begin with, this probably wont convince you otherwise. But if you like squishing peds and crushing cars, whilst being assaulted by crude, sexual innuendos, then it just might be for you!

It doesn't reinvent the wheel and it's a little rough around the edges, so I can't quite recommend it in it's current state, but hopefully a few patches and mod support will iron out the kinks down the line.

reviewText:
As a big fan of the old classics I have to say that sadly this does not live up to expectations.

What happened to all the buildings you could drive through? I remember in Carmageddon 2 and even TDR 2000 there were so many hidden places to go, buildings, underground caves, rooftops, random floors in buildings you somehow found all with powerups and peds in that just made the old ones so fun. You'd find something new every time!

Reincarnation just feels so empty. What happened to all these small things that made the game so great. Graphics limitations perhaps? Well I'd rather play C2 any day of the week compared to this.

I used to be an active member of the C2 community, not just in terms of forums but me and my friends used to 3d model and design cars for the game too. It was so much more of a flexible and versatile game, modding it became second nature.

There used to be so much more content to these games. I guess maybe alot of people would never have even seen the side to the classics that I have and played it vanilla" the entire time and if that's the case then maybe it's good in that sense? It does have some good features about it and it still fills me with feelings of nostalgia but at the same time it just feels like THERE IS ALOT MISSING.

For me Carmageddon was never just about smashing cars up and running over pedestriams
recommended: does anyone even remember the Airport levels in C2 for example? There would actually be planes taking off and landing
hoursPlayed: or the maps where you could just push a giant boulder down a hill for a laugh and kill peds or cars with it? or the street maps with actual traffic?  WHERE HAS IT ALL GONE?"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR
So far with this game i've had huge fun... but just because i know the carmagenddon franchise...
The game has far too many bugs and it is barely playable.

If you have a weak computer don't even bother buying this game as it is not optimised AT ALL.
I have a GTX980 (4GB) windforce overclocked and CPU i7 3770K(4.2ghz) and i played the game at 5760x1080 (eyefinity/surround) on maximum graphics settings. the game was around the cinematic 20FPS and with more complex scenes it dropped even lower... i couldn't set the resolution to 1920x1080 because the game would strech across my 3 monitors even with 16:9 aspect ratio.

The textures are popping (changing quality from low-res. to hi-res.) VERY often... it's basicaly a regular thing... some textures won't even load fully (at least i think because the road texture looks like it is from Golden Eye N64 for me)
There are numerous glitches with the water rendering especialy when inside water sometimes the whole world just disappears and you only see things (barels) that are 1m infront of the car. happens sometimes even when coming out of water.

The camera (please switch to rotating camera from default because the default back looking camera is AWFULL) it often gets inside buildings.

Loading times.... oh my god... it takes AGES to load i mean... it takes about a minute to load a race and about 30 seconds to go back to the menu...

Some of the races don't work at all and just give an error.

The game has great potential if they listen to the community AND I HOPE THEY WILL! because if not... then this game is going to have the reputation of being the worst of all Carmageddon games...

The Gameplay is great and the new powerups are too although it could stull use more... maybe i just haven't found them but  for example a pedestrian map, or a flying car (where the wheels rotate downwards and you can hover).
the pinball powerup slows the game down way too much... it's because it bounces around objects too...
the afterburner powerup was made worse from the older games by lifting up the front of the vehicle
it shouldn't imo. although the Hotrod powerup should.
It would be great to see the opponent ejector powerup (ejects the driver) if the driver had to run back to the car to drive it ,and if you killed him ,then the car would be just there not driving itself -.- (you'd still have to blow it up)

The physics are okay sometimes a bit too slidy (not enough friction).
i like how the car sticks to the walls a little bit  if you have some speed. It makes ramp stunts a lot easier.

I like how you can flip over your car if you get flipped over but the button to do so is the same as respawning the car so i often unintentionaly respawn myself instead of just flipping myself over.

The opponents are very dumb... almost brainless (it was somewhat excusable in Carma 1 but it could be improved here) they follow some basic rules and sometimes are way too easy to destroy (at least for my expectations on normal difficulty).
basicaly the game becomes way too easy after the first 2 races of getting used to the driving.
All in all the gameplay is mostly there.

it's great to see that it has controller support with different presets. Plug and play, easy. (Xbone controllers too)

unfortunetely i cannot recomend this game in it's current state as many people wouldn't enjoy it and get the full carmageddon experience out if it. i have played through all the Carmageddon games and the first game was my favourite.
this game tries to imitate and improve a lot of things but it needs a LOT of polish before it can be called a Good Carmageddon game
the only reason i'd recomend you buy thi game right now is because you get all the Carmageddon games for a very low price.

Developers please fix these bugs/problems so everyone can enjoy this soon to be amazing game.
voteText: 33 of 47 people (70%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Remember the good old Carmageddon where you decided to crush your enemies instead of driving all the laps until the race was over?

Oh, that was awesome, wasn't it?

If you enjoyed it, I recommend you to get the Carmageddon from the 90s.

In Carmageddon: Reincarnation, you don't need to bother with messing around with your opponents...it's not worth! You'll waste more money on the fixing costs of your car than you get as a reward for hitting and destroying them!

The only way to succeed by destroying your opponents is that you have to run over the yellow barrels and pedestrians. The pedestrians and most of the barrels give you 200 credits each. If you can spot the barrels that give you 500 you should go for these.

You have to run over barrels and kill pedestrians until you got enough credits to mess with the opponent racers...

...or you drive the laps and finish the race.,,up to you!

Do you want to mess with them anyway without collecting credits first? Forget that idea. You'll have minus values at the end of the race. That's the next point that sucks in the game: The level unlocking!

To Unlock new tier (3 new races/challenges), you have to collect credits. Let's say, you need 200,000 credits to unlock a new tier, you have to start a race in the current tier, and the credits you have collected by the end of the race will be substracted from that value. Repeat until it reaches 0, then it will be unlocked. Oh, you sucked this round and collected only 10,000 credits? Repeat, because you'll need 190,000 more!

Meanwhile you'll get bored!

reviewText:
Disappointed.

I backed this ages ago (2012?). I then played the beta briefly when it first appeared and thought it looked very rough but hoped they'd be able to sort it out in time.

Well now we're a long way down the line and the game has finally been released (albeit almost a month later than their original release date - not a problem, I don't mind waiting longer for a more polished experience). I think it needs another few months work. At least.

Graphically I think it looks pretty poor. It also doesn't run very well (I don't have the best rig, but I can play Project Cars at fairly decent settings which looks much nicer than this and has a far, far higher perceived framerate). Even turning the GFX settings down to best performance in C:R it was still very choppy.

As for the gameplay, its pretty much exactly as it was in the old games. Same humour. Same carnage. I'd expected more. At least a little more polish.

Pros
-same old Carmageddon

Cons
-poor visuals
-poor optimisation
-poor PED models (they look like something from Poser circa 2003)
-really long load times

Back to the garage for this one...

reviewText:
Before you keep reading you need to know I was a kickstarter backer of this game.

The game still needs more optimization to be done, even at very low resolutions and minimizing every detail the game runs at best 40ish FPS, I dare say Mortal Kombat X runs better.

The biggest problem besides optimization this game has its the clunky 1997 controls/steering and the sense of speed.

They haven't changed it since the original 1997 game, its like trying to steer a rocket but also you have no sense of speed, might as well have no tires since the forward impulsion takes over your car so much.
Your speedometer will say your car is going at 90 mph but it is moving so slow you won't believe it.

Anyone who has played any other racing game can tell you one of the most important aesthetic in it is the sense of speed, yea the game can tell you you are going X mph but if the game can't demonstrate it then it fails visually as a racing game, you have to be able to tell whether you are going fast or slow by the moving speed of the object which you control and the passage of the surrounding space(objects,buildings,cars,etc.) around you.

Me and a lot of backers have mentioned this problem before the game was in Early Access to the developer but they haven't changed anything and when mentioned to the community in its forums you get bombarded with over the top fanatic (How dare you"
recommended:
"**** you") reactions or with the typical:
"It controls exactly like a Carmaggedon game I don't see the problem."

Well I've mentioned the problems

The pros: Carmageddon is back.

The cons: Almost everything else.

Really, I'm incredibly disappointed in this one. I've wanted a Carmageddon reboot/sequel/prequel/anything for more than a decade. I've played on and off since early access (I dunno why Steam says I've only 2.4 hours on record and 0.3 in the past two weeks; I've played way more than that), and I've given the devs lots of leeway in my opinion as the game has evolved. reviewText: Until today I definitely wouldn't have recommended this to anyone. The game was so sluggish that it was virtually unplayable before the latest update. But after this update I can now play it with pretty much all settings maxed out (keeps AA off just in case) and have it run smoothly. And the core of the game was always solid. Now it is both solid AND playable. So now I can actually recommend it. As a game it manages to capture the spirit of the first two Carmageddon games while having somewhat modern graphics (I'd say pretty much on par with Race Driver: GRID... Better physics but a bit more rough models). A game like this which is basically a complete carnage open world will not run with the same level of detail as more dedicated racers where levels are smaller and more confined. I won't say it's a clean home run. But it is a good game.\n\n8/10

reviewText:
Okay, after long waiting second performance patch made it playable. If you can ran GTA5 all maxed out on 60fps - you probably can ran Carma all maxed out and hit at least 30. With accent on probably, be warned. Even fixed loading times (yeap, I've even tried to install the game on 5yo HDD with almost no impact on loading times, so if you don't have those funky expensive SSDs in your trusty old rig - you won't suffer). Steam Overlay can cause severe frame drops though when you get achievos or someone writes you. For some reason. And the game looks a bit better now too. So I'm changing my review to 'thumb up'.
Time to buy booyz. This is Carma with all stuff you expect from Carma and more. With great music too (as long as it isn't some god awful dubstep). Looks a bit better than previous games in series, and not on par on any recent game. But who cares as long as you can run over peds and bump into opponents. AI is dumb AF though, they often run in circles god know why. Car physics feel wierd, but nothng you can't get used to.

My only gripe now is that, sadly, it's a racing game without any sort of local multiplayer, no hotseat or split screen. I understand split screen is ton of work, but hotseat party mode could be great fun too and a lot easier to implement. After all it's the game that relies on replayability. Something Burnout-style hotseat mode could be really great.

reviewText:
I was an original backer of this project on kickstarter, and I was very excited about it. When it came out and I first tried it, I was still excited. Then it slowly dawned on me: this game is a complete ripoff of their original Carmageddon game, with almost nothing new added. It feels, sounds and plays EXACTLY the same. I'm serious, even the sound effects are the same, the levels are the same only with relatively better graphics (still looks outdated), and even the cars are the same.

Maybe I misunderstood the aim of the project, but if I knew it was only going to be a remake, I wouldn't have bothered. The original Carmageddon formula was a novelty at the time when it came out, and the destruction and mayhem is still certainly fun today, but some things just aged very badly. One of those things is the driving mechanics. I'ts horrible, slow, unwieldy and just plain un-fun. Driving games just became so much better since then, so I don't understand why painstakingly reproduce the same boring driving mechanics, when it could have been so much better.

A game that I hoped for is a modern, fast-paced, action packed take on the carmageddon franchise, with the same brutal fun that it used to be, but with modernized driving mechanics. What I got is a HD remake with a few extra game modes thrown in.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game brought tears of joy to my eyes.

Carmageddon: Reincarnation is an awesome update of the Carmageddon series. It has time-warped me back to my younger years when I was hooked on Carmageddon 1 and 2, and man do I have great memories that come with that.

So what's it like?

Production values are very high here, you'll notice that as soon as you see the game's splash screen. This is no cheap, minimum effort cash grab, at all. The graphic design, the whole visual style, the interface, the music; it's all of very quality. There is a nice number of image quality options to play with, too.

Next thing you'll notice is that there is a very nice number of tracks, cars and game modes. I can see dozens or perhaps hundreds of hours here. And I don't even play multi...

I was blown away by the game the moment the first race began. I don't even know where to start here... The physics are as great as they have always been in the Carmageddon games. They nailed the driving model, too. The AI is really aggressive, and it's a joy to race and trade paint with them. The graphics are beautiful! Having Vlad's dragster coming at you at full speed, with these huge flames coming out of its exhausts, is absolutely awesome! The graphics were never the biggest star in Carmageddon, but man this has changed. This game is a joy for the eyes, and combined with the great physics it is a total blast. The music is very fitting as well, it's mostly hard-rock, and I once got a dub step track, too, that was surprisingly tolerable.

Performance was very nice on my machine, an i5 4690k with 8gb of RAM and a 4gb AMD R9 290 GPU. Streaming to my laptop worked nicely as well.

This game will become a classic. I want a physical release please!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Time for another review. This time Carmageddon: Reincarnation gets the low-down.

First of all, I have a huge nostalgia of the original Carmageddon game, so take from that what you will. Onwards!

I've played this game now for roughly 6 hours, so I have had a good taste of what this game has to offer. First up I felt like I was smack bang in the action from the word Go! The nostalgia of the cars, especially the first one you are given is obvious, and the crazy handling seemed reminiscent of the original game as well. The first race is more of a trial, with an integrated tutorial to help you get the hang of the game and what you're supposed to do - although NOT EVERYTHING appears to get explained - I had myself to find out a few races later how I could switch weapons/power-ups. So, this tutorial could have been implemented better; still, I'm not complaining too much.

The game modes are great from what I've played, and seem more like Insane 2 racing game (minus the obvious pedestrians!) than what I remember of the original carmageddon. This looks to be well implemented, and I've really had a blast trying to complete classic carmaggedon races in the three different modes (complete the race, take out all other cars, and wipe out all peds - excuse the pun). Overall, some good diversity with the other modes going on as well. The sound is pretty good, and I don't notice too much repitition cos there always seems to be a lot going on anyway. Graphics look ok, though not amazing given this is meant to be a new game (Bugbear's game looks a lot better).

So, you really want me to tell you what's wrong now I guess? Like others have already mentioned, there are looooooooooooooooooooooong loading times, there is illogical lagging in game as well for seconds at a time, and ultimately this has put me down to thinking the graphics aren't optimised.

In conclusion, the lack of graphical optimization makes this game completely frustrating at times, and the loading times are bloody annoying as well. If the devs sort out the graphical lag, then I can forgive the long loading times. Normally I wouldn't buy EAG, but I bought this half price cos I saw the classic Carmageddon games being bundled in with this as well. At full price you will get frustrated, and probably not get your money's worth of enjoyment. I will be glad to change this from not recommended to recommended if the lag/graphical issues are resolved. Do it for us, devs.

reviewText:
Video of the original review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MFXzJeEOans

EDIT:
The performance issues have been hugely improved, props to the developers for continuing to iron that out! Load times are still abysmal even on an SSD, but that's minor compared to the horrible performance of the past. Additionally, there are new features made available for free that make it even better than it already was. Finally, I can enjoy this one without feeling ripped off :)

TL;DR Enjoyable 90's-throwback gameplay, but questionable performance.

Straight up, I am a huge Carmageddon fan. I bought and played through every game several times, even the censored zombie and robot versions and TDR2000. So of course, I had to back the new one on Kickstarter as soon as I saw it. With that said, Carmageddon Reincarnation is something I question spending all that cash on.

We‚Äôll come back to that, but here‚Äôs the setup: Carmageddon Reincarnation is the fourth official entry in the series that began back in 1997 on MS-DOS. It's a racing game with a nonsensical, graphically violent, comedic slant, acting as a tribute to movies like Death Race 2000 and The Road Warrior. Stainless Games, the developer of the first two and easily the games in the series, are back again to bring this gore fest of a racer to the audiences of 2015. Of course, quite a bit has changed since the 90‚Äôs, and gory games rarely draw crowds based on gore alone like they used to. So beyond the copious guts, the main draw of Carmageddon is the vehicular destruction and racing, and Reincarnation brings its A game in that regard. While you can play a free race using any cars and tracks you‚Äôve unlocked, it‚Äôs the career mode that features the blood-soaked meat of the game. Just like old times, you‚Äôll select from either Max Damage or Die Anna, which come with their own unique cars to start out with. Then you‚Äôll progress through the career as fast as you can manage, with each race having a different set of objectives to complete.

But unlike many other racers, Carmageddon is all about freedom to do whatever the nuts you want. If you don‚Äôt want to run through checkpoints, why not just run through opposing drivers instead? Or slice through those squishy pedestrians, earning time and points the more creatively you murder them? However, not all races allow you to win in this way, since there are other modes that force you to play by the rules. Sort of. For instance, there are races where you‚Äôll have to race through certain spots on the map or run over select pedestrians, and whoever first reaches the set number wins. But if you don‚Äôt want to bother, you can always try to destroy the drivers that are playing by the rules, and for each kill you‚Äôll steal a point of theirs. So even when restrictions appear, there‚Äôs always an alternative and often more enjoyable method. It‚Äôs the Carmageddon way. And each race takes place in a completely open map, so you‚Äôre free to roam around looking for cool stuff, usually in the form of power-ups. All the classics from the old games are back, and there are plenty of new ones that up the daft sadist factor by a solid amount. You can now stack several of them too, so anything you collect that isn‚Äôt controlled by a timer can be kept in your inventory and deployed at will. It‚Äôs just as fun as ever to turn your car into granite, make pedestrians explode on contact, or repel other cars with giant springs. And yes, the power-downs are all here as well, making it an enticing gamble to collect any pickups. But it‚Äôs also a game that‚Äôs quite forgiving, since you can always repair or reset your car at any time, even if you‚Äôre out of points to do so or have been completely wasted. And I absolutely love how when you repair your car, the parts come flying in from wherever they fell off, slicing through anyone along the way back to you.

In regards to the physics, I have no complaints as a Carmageddon 1 and 2 fan. The cars feel heavy, the handling feels slick, and the damage model is as impressive as it‚Äôs ever been. The way cars deform, crumble, and fall apart, from the bumpers all the way down to the chassis, is uniquely satisfying. (Although I haven‚Äôt found a way to shear my car in half like you could in Carmageddon 2, but maybe I just wasn‚Äôt trying hard enough.) It‚Äôs important in these games to feel powerful yet vulnerable, because one lucky hit from an opponent or a police car will absolutely ruin you even at full health. Of course, not only can unlock more cars, you can also upgrade cars with armor, power, and offensive upgrades. You can even change the paintwork and rims now, which is a very welcome touch when you‚Äôre trying to max out a specific vehicle but get bored of the same look. Upgrades work similarly to Carmageddon 2, in that you have to find APO upgrade tokens hidden around the maps which allow you to place upgrades. But this time, you can only earn upgrade slots as you level up your profile in career mode, which is done by earning career experience points during each race. The more you suck though, the more points you‚Äôll spend on repairs and resets, and the longer it‚Äôll take to level up. I can‚Äôt say I‚Äôm sold on this personally, because it‚Äôs one of those systems where you‚Äôll have to replay certain missions over and over just to grind an arbitrary number of points to progress. There‚Äôs plenty of gameplay and replaying of each map without being held back like this, so I wish you could just give career levels the finger, like every other rule in the game.

There‚Äôs something else I‚Äôd like to give the finger to: the performance. The graphical performance in Carmageddon Reincarnation sucks. My system easily surpasses the recommended specs and can play any other open world game at consistently high frame rates with ease. Even on low graphics settings with a 4GB GTX770 Superclocked and FX-8350, I can barely reach an average of 40fps here, and it‚Äôs not uncommon at all for some stages to run in the single digits. Not only that but the load times are abysmal, taking up to two minutes to load certain races, and this is running on an SSD. For a 2015 game that looks like something from 2005, this is unacceptable. I can accept low-quality graphics, but not with low performance on top of that. And that‚Äôs just single player, multiplayer is even worse, which is a shame because online Carmageddon is always a blast.

And this SHOULD be a blast, because overall I‚Äôm very happy with how Reincarnation turned out. When it was running half-decently, I was grinning like a doofus, completely content with smashing up post-apocalyptic cars and crashing through pane glass windows while literally farting on my opponents. But when things get even slightly chaotic, things slow to a crawl or even straight up enter slideshow mode. It‚Äôs sad, because otherwise I‚Äôd have little problem recommending this at its asking price. The performance has improved since the beta, that‚Äôs for sure, but it‚Äôs still completely unplayable on one of my systems, and barely playable on my best PC. So until this is fixed, hold out for a sale. While the fun is there, the ability to fully enjoy it without a very specific computer setup is not. At any rate, there‚Äôs at least a new game in the chaotic Carmageddon series to enjoy now. I just wish the only chaotic thing about it was the gameplay, instead of the playability.
voteText: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Big warning beforehand: For now, in the beta, the optimization is crap. I didn't have any crashes (unlike the last time a couple months ago), but the graphics are laggy even on low-med, and the slowdown is real on certain events (like pinball). That all said;

CRAZY FUN. The cars, the tracks, the power-ups, the action, the race styles, all come together to make an absolutely exhilarating experience.

The tracks are well put together with the action in mind, expanding onto multiple levels. The cars are varied in control styles and all very fun to drive. The humour, while not normally my style, fits into and enhances the game as a whole.

Make no mistake, it is Carmageddon. The proper rebirth of the series with a graphic and technological spruce-up of the original (if not very visible at this stage, see forewarning), and some elements either brought from Carma2 or new creations, this keeps all the fun of the two originals. (we don't talk about the other one)

The multiplayer, which was the longest fun of the old ones, is even more fun with friends, but the game's optimization at this stage is unfortunately even more apparent, with FPS dipping even further than in SP and occasional disconnects. Very much looking forward to the optimization progress on this front.

While the problems of the beta are still apparent, the progress is real and visible; with almost if not all of the content already there, optimization and improvements is the main focus of the developers, which is a cause for relief and hope after seeing many other projects fall behind their own ambition.

If you loved the old Carmas, there can be no reason to not go for it. If you haven't but it seems like your thing, maybe wait for it to get closer to its proper form and see for yourself then, but my cynicism has been dispelled by the beta already.

reviewText:
Reincarnation is now becoming what it was meant to be.
Being a kickstarter game, then a greenlight project, the game had a rough launch, with poor perfomance, subpar graphics and visible unachieved potential.

Since the release, developers have released two big patches that gave better looks and performance to the game.
The latest update (update 2) finally makes Carmageddon: Reincarnation reach the level fans of the series were expecting.

If you like Carmageddon and want a new, gorier and prettier version, buy it.
Be aware that because of it's origins it still has some rough edges (it's no AAA game), like some menus are clunky and there is an old-school feel in it (no cinematics, story, etc.), but the potential the devs aimed at are now being achieved and it is pure fun (Destruction, speed, chaos and gore never looked better on carma).

Also, if you are worried about the overall quality and perfomance, just be aware that the developers are giving constant support to the game, updating, upgrading and giving feedback on their status.

Totally recommend for carmafans.

reviewText:
It pains me to write this review. I had, like many other, pre-ordered this game while it was in the kickstarting phase to recreate my joyous childhood. I waited, and waited, and waited, and EVENTUALLY the alpha came out. It was nearly unplayable for me; too many bugs, crashed, etc...

So I waited till the beta was coming out. Similar problems, ran a little better. I was kind of shocked that the game was coming out as quickly as it was supposed to at that point. It definitely wasn't polished and was not ready. BUT I had hopes. I believed in the game.

By all means my computer is not a bad computer. I don't have problems or trouble running any games at the highest or ultra settings. The lag, graphical hickups, and other messload of problems make this game almost unenjoyable. I have at least found $15 worth of enjoyment, but I will be putting it to the side till these problems are hopefully addressed.

Wait it out. This game was not ready to be released and it was a major disappointment to all those who waited with open arms.

reviewText:
After the last update, the game has finally been given the treatment it needed.

It's the definitive sequel for Carmageddon 2, and the third installment every Carmageddon fan deserved.

Insane physics, crazy powerups, tne gameplay is lots of fun and all the wackiness you can expect from a Carma game is there, freshly kept but updated with HD graphics and updated technology.

Not only has the performance improved, but further optimisation is coming, along with more content (such as tech for 6-wheeled cars like the Supressor (temporaly replaced by its 4-wheeled subpressor brother), tech for 2-wheeled vehicles and tracked vehicles such as Kingmerc and Project-X, both from the original Carmageddon).

This game is a blast, running over pedestrians and cows with the updated technology and improved graphics make this game a must for every car-combat wacko out there.

If you loved Carmageddon Max Pack and Carmageddon 2, this is the game for you.

I was recently asked by one of the developers to re-try the game since it had been patched and I'm glad she did. The patch takes care of SO many issues that I decided to remove my previous review (not recommended) and turn that QQ-list into a wishlist on this review where I do recommend the game.

# Bigger levels

Issues/complains:
# Can't disable controller
# If a controller is physically removed the last command it gave (turning left for instance) will remain until you restart the game
# Keys are localized despite game, client and OS is in english

reviewText:
Max is back!

If you was ever a fan of the old Carmageddon games, you'll love this. It is one of the most faithful remakes I've ever seen, it uses the same in-house engine as the old games did to retain that classic Carmageddon feel, but with shiny new graphics, some new power ups and new cars thrown in for good measure, and online multiplayer!

They recently released an update bringing improved performance and improved graphics, which is lovley.. And on top of that they still have plenty of future updates planned too! It's a labour of love and anyone who was looking to get that classic carma gameplay in a new package should buy this game immediately, old school gameplay with modern graphics!

Recommended.

reviewText: Played and loved all the Carmageddon games over the years, but this one is unplayable because the cars are so hard to control you feel like you're driving on ice all of the time and it is incredibly frustrating. I don't mind the bad graphics and thankfully my PC has the resources for this game to hog, but in its current form the cars are just totally unresponsive and just start spinning out no matter what you do. The irony is that you're supposed to run down peds, hit other cars, maneuver around to get to strategically located checkpoints... but you can't even swerve onto the sidewalk to hit a ped without going into a tailspin, it feels like it takes all day to accelerate to hit someone who you end up missing anyway because when you turn you just lose all control. Good grief.  As of 5/23/2015 the basic game mechanics are so bad I wish I hadn't got the game.

reviewText:
I have absolutely no idea why this game is mostly positive because frankly, it's a terrible view on Carmageddon and nothing like the original...

Firstly, the simple most BASIC of issues...  You don't just 'wreck them' to win.  It's really that damned simple, keep the wrecked the same as it was in the originals.  That's ALL you had to do...

Instead, they have turned it into a modern shooter with cars, where your enemies simply respawn on dying.  I'm sorry, but that's not Carmageddon...  The game was about winning the race by wrecking all your opponents to stop 'them' winning.  To remove this and just have them respawn makes it's just a race to kill the enemy before they kill themselves.

Which brings me to the second problem...  The cars have no clout and no speed.  At least early on, which is about as long as I can give this...  I was going full speed, hit someone once, slowed to a crawl and didn't kill them...  The cars just stopped dead.  Couldn't charge him into a wall or anything, just had to reverse, but couldn't do that because the other car simply moved forward at the exact same speed anyway, so restore was the only option.

Which brings me to my last major bone of contention here...  The loading screens.  They've made an improvement on optimisation I'll give them that, but the loading screens are absolutely atrocious.  I have a fast CPU and a damned good GPU, yet I was sat waiting through 5mins of loading screens for a 10 minute race.  50% loading/playing time is NOT acceptable for a decent rig.

Simply put I cannot and do not recommend this game, not to fans of the originals, or those looking to try it out.

reviewText:
FInally, I can recommend this game! The new patch has fixed quite a few performance issues, sans loading times (in the works apparently), and added a nice coat of graphical polish.

Vehicular combat games have fallen by the wayside, growing up with Twisted Metal and Vigilante 8 it's been a favorite genre of mine for some time. Crashing and blowing up cars is just too fun, so it's good to see a new entry from an old series.

The levels are huge, unfortunately so are the loading times ;_; but once you're in you can spend while trying to complete the objectives. So while loading may take up a noticible percentage of playtime, it's burried in the time spent running over hundreds of peds or chasing down the last oppenent to wreck.

The car models look great, especially now. Engines shaking and spikes skewering peds are nice touches. The cars feel unique from each other and mixing it up adds fun and makes each run feel different.

If you're looking for a car combat game with just the right amount of crass humor (All the wrecked 'ems!") Pick up this game. It's fun

reviewText:
As a massive Carma 1 & 2 (maybe a little bit of 3) fan and a backer since Pre-Alpha I can't recommend this. Performance issues aside the new physics feel terrible and at high speeds the cars aren't fun to drive. It's wonky and frustrating even by Carma standards. I wasn't expecting BeamNG.drive quality or a sim racer, but I was at least hoping for what they did with the Android port of Carma 1, but seriously, is asking for a traction model too much? Instead the car jitters like it's resisting oversteer and then spins out.

I think they were trying to make the game more accessible but all of the old Carma frustrations are still there, which will probably drive away newcomers. On top of that most of the maps and vehicles are locked behind a grindy progression system. I enjoyed the Alpha because I could play with all the toys as I saw fit.

This game is actually quite fun to ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• around in, but having to drive the same maps over and over again with the same two cars to unlock anything kills it for me. For a game with such a sarcastic tone, it takes its progressive gameplay way too seriously.

Well, esthetically the game is pleasing for the fans, and the new ice map is awesome! But I can't stand the third person camera and the only other option is bumper cam! No hood cam? Hell, if this is a throwback game, where the hell are the detailed cockpits I can look around it? At least do what Carma 2 did and put the camera inside the model. The devs talked about that on their forums, but it never happened.

All and all I didn't get what I wanted for $30. It's not HD Carma 1, and it's certainly not a progression off Carma 2. I would recommend any of the old games or the smartphone port over this game if you don't already own them. Except for the N64 port obviously.

AFTER UPDATE 2!!!
Well now, after two patches the game has become much more playable. They even upped the graphics, making it look better as well as running better.
While the controls are the same, clunky mess, its just not running at -12 fps anymore, so turning and reacting to situations have become easier.
Loadtimes are still long, but like I've stated several times now; it looks better and runs better so it can be excused for having long loadtimes.
I'll leave the old review in here, since the game is still the same fun game, its just updated ;)


Old Early Access review:

Clunky controls, lackluster graphics, long loadtimes, poorly optimized, but this game really grows on you.

Its a remake of one of my most favored childhood games, and its a really good modern interpretation.
It keeps the oldschool feel, while updating the visuals. Its still basically Deathrace 2000, and it is awesome!
Worth most of its value.

The bad parts are as I mentioned:
It has very clunky controls. The cars just does not behave like you want them to. I guess its trying to keep the way the cars handled in the original, but its still fudgin clunky and messy.
The lackluster graphics. Yeah, it does not look like a game from 2014 now does it.
Long loadtimes and poorly optimized. For a game with these visuals and not all that great attention to detail, why does it load this slow and run this poorly? I guess the physics might be to blame, but its not all that impressive, at least when taking the long loadtimes and how it runs into account.
I do commend them for the repair" animation though. When your car is getting a severe hammering
date: repairing your vehicle makes it morph into its original form
recommended: while all the lost car parts fly into place from all over the map

reviewText:
As a massive Carma 1 & 2 (maybe a little bit of 3) fan and a backer since Pre-Alpha I can't recommend this. Performance issues aside the new physics feel terrible and at high speeds the cars aren't fun to drive. It's wonky and frustrating even by Carma standards. I wasn't expecting BeamNG.drive quality or a sim racer, but I was at least hoping for what they did with the Android port of Carma 1, but seriously, is asking for a traction model too much? Instead the car jitters like it's resisting oversteer and then spins out.

I think they were trying to make the game more accessible but all of the old Carma frustrations are still there, which will probably drive away newcomers. On top of that most of the maps and vehicles are locked behind a grindy progression system. I enjoyed the Alpha because I could play with all the toys as I saw fit.

This game is actually quite fun to ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• around in, but having to drive the same maps over and over again with the same two cars to unlock anything kills it for me. For a game with such a sarcastic tone, it takes its progressive gameplay way too seriously.

Well, esthetically the game is pleasing for the fans, and the new ice map is awesome! But I can't stand the third person camera and the only other option is bumper cam! No hood cam? Hell, if this is a throwback game, where the hell are the detailed cockpits I can look around it? At least do what Carma 2 did and put the camera inside the model. The devs talked about that on their forums, but it never happened.

All and all I didn't get what I wanted for $30. It's not HD Carma 1, and it's certainly not a progression off Carma 2. I would recommend any of the old games or the smartphone port over this game if you don't already own them. Except for the N64 port obviously.

reviewText:
I love this game. It works great for me, unfortunately thats not the case for everyone. It seems a lot of people are mad that Carmageddon has been faithfully recreated. It's not new gameplay, it's just updated. If you played the original Carmageddons the this should be right up your alley. However, it is the same game as in 97, it has not grown up along with us. You may have liked the gameplay more as a ten year old.
I still love it, I've got tons of time into it and for those of us who aren't all about the graphics you will find a great game in here that's rough around the edges. Got loading troubles, vsync off my friends, vsync off.
Heres some gameplay from the multiplayer mode : https://youtu.be/JnFpz4tADLU
It's Carmageddon people, and just wait until some modders get a hold of it and run off with new cars and maps and graphics.

Update:It now loads fine, runs well, and looks so pretty. More cars have been added as well as another 14 car mods made by Mad Mikes Productions if your interested in finding them. Multiplayer works well, so if you've got friends you want to play it with don't be afraid of that. They have addressed almost all of what was holding the game back, and I believe the owners of this title WILL get Max Damage as a free update.

reviewText:
Redoing mnost of this review and i deleted my alpha reveiw as it no longer applies here

My Specs

AMD FX-8350 8 core cpu @4.0 ghz
Radeon HD 7870 Tahiti MYST edition 2 GB GDDR5 ram (runs closer to a 7950 because it uses that core not a standard 7870 core)
16 gig PC 1866 DDR3 ram


BETA UPDATE:
Ok after more extensive playing around i got an ok graphic setting  that still get's playable frame rates (that's playable for my opinion your's may differ)

FINAL PRODUCT UPDATE:

Well it stil runs like sh-- in a tub.
i'm on 1080p  but changing to 720 p makes NO difference in playability.
They removed many graphic selections  such as texture  added a few others that seem to have no impact .  Shadows and reflections are still the biggest frame rate killers. Seems they have done nothing in in optimizing how their engines pulls those effects off, As turning either of those on above low severely cripples the frame rate.

PATCH UPDATE:    stainless finnally coded the game to multithread, it's made huge frame rate improvements  IGNORE every thing i previously said about the game runnign like s--- in a tub.  it runs great now.


That said with shadows off , AO off and reflections on low  i can keep a frame rate between 29-50 (with heavy Jumps between those two numbers)
Playable but sad given the level of fidelity" this game is out putting. Seriously i can run Far cry 3 and 4 at 45-60 fps on this machine  and this game doesn't have half what those games got going on graphically. I blame the Engine it's self. Often new game engines are the greatest problem for frame rates.  why did Stainless have to make their own engine?  why didn't they just license an engine and save money the end result would have looked better. cry engine 3 and UDK 4 both run better and look better  by miles on my PC compared to this game's engine. Hell even UDK 3 would have been better and that engine came out in 2007.


again you may or may not consider these playable frame rates  but i find it easy to enjoy the game and have  encounterd only a few slowdowns or stutters.

Graphic quibbles out of the way I'm gonna break this down in to several cata-gore-eez

Changes to the career mode (this is not your grandpa's carmagedon)-

the career mode is awesome.  you can now choose to be Die-anna  or Max
date: and this choice is also seperate of your car choice (that being you pick your racer and when you change cars as you progress
recommended: you stil have that racer).\n\nYou also now can change your car color ... YES!!!  this is something i always wanted in the old Carma games but  well they just never had it.  Now you can make that awesome eagle black
hoursPlayed: or you can make the hawk pink.  That said the color  choices are not as broad as i'd have hoped for.  other race games let you paint the car  using a color scale like what you'd find in a paint software.  Well that's not here
voteText:
you just get  to choose from a set of predefined colors.  That's not bad though as the old carma games had no way to change car color so even this limited addition is a fresh breath of air for the series.

Game Modes (new ways to run people over) -

The death race mode is a much needed addition to the carmagedon series as it actually encoruages you to race as opposed to just smashing the hell out of your opponents.

Alternately the Check point Stampede mode is alsoa  fun addition to the game play.  Very unique mode. it's hard to compare it to any other game's play modes .. just try it out it's fun. I'd say it's like  king of the hill meets capture the flag  all done in fast cars while said hill/flag moves around.

I haven't seen any other game modes  other than those two and classic carmageddon mode
helpfulPercent:
but then i'm not very deep into the game. I'm only a few hours in and I've jsut got to the second set of races.



Overview thoughts.   Given what I';ve seen and how much i've played already  I'd say the game is looking BIG. Far more massive than the short walk games we have gotten used to today.  Now if only Stainless games would get to optimising it better.  I want at least medium image quality shadows/DoF/MB  on
votesHelpful: with medium car reflections  to run at 35+ fps  @ 1080p by the time the game is finished (gold).  If they fall short of that then i may have to rate the game low. There's no reason this game should be so abussive to hardware when it is finished.\n\nOne cool thing about this carmageddon is the cars are best handling ever.  in the old carmagedon games car ahndling was often an issue (especially in 2). well not here most eh cars handle wee
votesTotal: but you stil find your self occasionally flyign around (which is a fun flying around not a "god damn why won't this car respond right" flying around). so yeah car handling is great  and generally designed for maximum fun game play.\nany way as it stands now
votesFunny: a power system is reccomended for sure.  again look at my spec listing above.  Sure my comp is a year old but it is by no means an "average man's (or woman's)"  PC.\n\nALL THAT SAID!
commentsCount: AS FAR AS AN EARLY ACESS GAME GOES. THIS ONE IS WORTH IT ESPECIALLY AT THE BETA  BUILD

IF YOU GOT THE HARDWARE TO HANDLE IT.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This essentially takes the best parts of Carma 1 and 2 and brings them well up to date. The cars are awesome, subtle little changes compared to originals gives them their own style without changing the character. The maps are quite big and use a lot of vertical space, kind of like Maim Street in Carma 2. There's a good mix of old and new powerups too.

Most of the complaints are about frame rate and load times so I'll address those directly:
The load times are pretty huge, it does take 30-40 seconds to load a map, sometimes a bit longer.
I don't have any issues once it's loaded with SLI GTX 670s and an i5 CPU running at 4ghz but my HTPC that runs Grid 2 beautifully is a slide show (1-2 fps) so I guess it's a bit hit and miss.

My only complaint is how it feels like all the cars have the oiled up tyres debuff. Seriously, make a turn at ~60kph and you slide into a wall. It makes exploring the tight maps and checkpoint stampede really frustrating because it feels like you're steering a boat. I'm sure it'll improve with the handling upgrades but that's a long way off in the campaign. Also the engine sounds get really annoying really quickly (I changed the engine sounds in Carma 2 to an actual V8 and it sounded f*cking amazing).

It's not the kind of game I can play for hours at a time, but it's awesome for a quick 30 minute destress every now and then :)

reviewText: This game might be worth playing in the future, but it certainly isn't now.  On powerful gaming machines you have to turn all graphics settings to low just to hit 60 fps, with no hope of maintaining it for more than short periods during races.  Crashing into other cars will still drop below 30.  On maximum settings, I can barely break 20.  Loading times are longer than Battlefield 4.  This is in a game that looks like a last gen console launch title (the graphical quality and game style remind me of a lot of the PS3 launch title Motorstorm actually.)  On top of that, the cars handle like you're driving on ice and doesn't really have anything more to offer than the 18 year old original.\n\nStay away unless the developers produce a miracle and actually make it playable.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you're a fan of the old Carmageddon games and you're wondering Is this new game just as good?" the answer is YES!

WHAT IS CARMAGEDDON?:
Carmageddon is like a crazy demolition derby with insane weapons (like zapping pedestrians with lightning or using a gravity vacuum to literally suck parts off opponent cars to name a few)!
The best way I could describe Reincarnation is a cross between Mario Kart and Twisted Metal. Depending on the map you select
date: you're free to explore that entire level at your leisure while having the option to win the match in three different ways.\nThe objective is to either race through all the checkpoints (you can take any route you want to reach them but usually there's a set path your opponents take) or kill everyone before they can finish the race! You can also win by killing every pedestrian on the map
recommended: but this is usually very difficult and time consuming.\nThe game also includes bots incase you don't want to play online
hoursPlayed:
which brings us to our next topic..

WHAT'S NEW WITH BETA?:
I've played both the Alpha version and Beta version and I can tell you there's been a huge increase in performance! The game still isn't optimized very well and requires a pretty beefy computer just to play it on medium settings
voteText: but framerate is a lot more stable and the game doesn't feel like it's going to explode anymore.\nThis increase in performance is so noticable
helpfulPercent: I expect optimization to be completely ironed out on the games full release (it's not going to stay broken).\nI'll also point out that despite the game running perfectly fine for me
votesHelpful: I've had it crash more with the Beta version than Alpha.\n\nThe most notable additions for the Beta is the inclusion of an online Multiplayer and a full fleshed out Career Mode with unlockable cars & levels! You can also collect tokens √† la Diddy Kong Racing inside levels. These are spent on new parts for customization. Some just increase a stat of armour
votesTotal: but others have more of a visual impact
votesFunny: like adding a giant drill on the front) XD\nAlso the Beta version now includes every car
commentsCount: but now you have to unlock them (in Alpha everything was unlocked).\nBe warned: I've had the game run without any problems only to randomly crash after completing a match
column16: thus not saving my progress. The Single Player game is technically beatable
column17: but it's not stable enough to do so without repeating a few rounds. Play this game for fun
column18:
not to beat it! ..at least for now.

EARLY ACCESS:
If you're concerned about this being just another game in Early Access that wants your money but won't be released
column19: that's not the case. This isn't a random indie team with overly high ambitious promises
column20: it's a professional gaming company. The same company that created all previous Carmageddon titles! And if you're concerned your PC can't handle it
column21:
Reincarnation will have a console release :)

FINAL THOUGHTS:
At the time of writing this review
column22: your purchase of Reincarnation includes Carmageddon 1
column23: 2 & TDR. I think they're always going to have that deal
column24: bit I can't be sure. The inclusion of the classic games is already worth it in my opinion! They've touched up the graphics on the classic games (only a little bit) and some of them even include an online multiplayer :D\nIf you're looking for a solid racing game
column25: Carmageddon might not be for you. The controls are tight for a demolition derby
column26: but I found racing to be the most frustrating aspect.. especially since the cars act more like tanks.\nIf you're a fan of the old games
column27: you won't regret this purchase. Straight up

reviewText: When I like a game a lot, as I did Carmageddon 2, and it has a lot of replayability potential there's no need to change anything about it. As time goes though, the graphics become outdated and the content (levels in this case) becomes somewhat boring. So what's the easy solution to make the game great again after all the years? Improve the graphics and add more content. Carmageddon: Reincarnation does just that, keeping everything else intact and making it feel like Carmageddon 2 and the year is 1998, not 2015.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I got this in Early Access before the February 2015 Pubic Beta update. Back then, the game was borderline unplayable due to long loading times and sub-standard performance during the game. Would I recommend the game in such a state ? Nope. Not at all. Still, being a fan of the original 2 Carmageddon games (except the mission levels in 2 - screw those) I kept my fingers crossed hoping my money wasn't wasted in the long run, and that TDR2000 would remain the turd in the series.

Flash forward to a few months later with precious little updates from the devs in between, and we're past said February 2015 update. At this point, the game has undergone an engine rewrite, but whoever's building the levels etc. hasn't been idle either.
The result so far: A game that might still crash on occasion (have had that happen once), but that is otherwise pretty complete. It runs smooth enough on a medium-powered rig (if you don't set all graphic details to full), and really plays like classic Carma with a few updated twists to it - mostly more moving parts on the maps, and new game modes.

All the classic stuff is there:

- Most of the cars from 1 & 2, along with a few new ones. (Sadly, none of the new ones from TDR2000 which despite it's flaws does have some fun designs)
- Classic powerups such as the pinball mode, instant handbrake, and of course the Pedestrian Electro-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• Ray
- Even a number of maps are based off the ones from the old games.
- And the all-mighty cop cars that will wreck you in short order, unless you come prepared with powerups etc. to take them on. And yes, you'll find them quick enough if you go off track to hunt peds.

The new stuff:
- New powerups which are twists on existing ones (anvil launcher to go along the slaughter mortar, tossers & vacuums to go along with repulsificator springs)
- And just new powerups, such as the Silent But Deadly ped-killing toxic cloud, the Spinnertron which spins your car (yep) and mainly for style bonuses but can help make corners at insane speeds if mastered, and the Pelvic Thrust which is a short but powerful speed boost.
- New powerdowns are there as well of course, such as Feelin' Fragile" which boosts damage taken and makes your car look like glass.
- And new game modes that aren't missions that suck ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. They're mainly objective hunts (checkpoints or peds) or pure races where your opponents will respawn. Wrecking them is still a good way to take and hold the lead though :)

The car upgrade system has also been reworked- you now have to scout the maps for upgrade tokens during the campaign mode
date: with the different power levels unlocking along the way too.\n\nAll in all
recommended: this is now the Carmageddon I wanted to see. It takes what was good in the first 2
hoursPlayed: and builds on that. And it's still as politically incorrect and insane as the series ever was."

reviewText:
EDIT2: After the second patch the performance is more or less on the same level as the first patch, maybe a couple of fps more, there are still noticeable frame drops from time to time and damage model seems to have taken another hit. I still havent managed to split my car. Overall, i can now recomend this game, but only to carma die hard fans. In all honesty, carma 2 is still way better game with more and larger environments, more cars and more things to do.
Oh, and no matter what some stupid ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•s claim, not all negative reviews are outdated.



EDIT: After the patch the game performs much better, althou still not at an acceptable level but it is getting there, one more such patch and my review shall surely be changed to a more positive one.

The game-play itself is super fun, especially for long time Carma fans, myself included, BUT

performance of the game is horrible, on fx-8150@5GHz, 16GB of VERY fast RAM and 260x with 2GB of GDDR5 on medium details(and even on low, no significant performance difference) the FPS OFTEN dips under 40fps which usually ends up with you missing an opponent or objective and ruins the fun, all of that while my cpu, ram and gpu are no where near 100% load, the game uses like 2 gigs of ram, uses maybe 50% of the cpu and less than 70% gpu...


even thou the game looks outdated(not important really) there is no PC capable to run it a constant 60FPS on modern monitor resolutions, I even doubt that anyone has a stable 30fps that never dips under that

unless the devs decide to dump the engine that has its roots in the first carma game, which is absolutely absurd, this game will probably never work properly, at least not in the next several years

overal, would be a damn great game if it used modern hardware properly and not dependant on single core performance

reviewText:
Alright, review time. So far, i've played a total of 5.2 hours, and although those hours were spent in RELATIVE enjoyment, I can't say I love the game, and it's for a few reasons.

The biggest and most annoying reason being that most cars feel like sleds. It just feels like they barely have any grip at all.
This is made worse by my second gripe, the fact that the car gets stuck on stupid things like limbs from pedestrians. I've stopped counting the amount of times i've had to come to a full stop, reverse, and scoot over to the left or right, because there was an arm stuck to the front of my sled, making it handle even worse.
Thirdly, the upgrade system for your cars. Who the hell thought it would be a good idea to add upgrade tokens to carma? Who was it? I would like this person to be publicly punished. What was wrong with buying your upgrades with your hard earned cash?
And then there's the performence issue. The game does not perform very well. It has frequent frame drops, and this makes handling your sleds even harder than it already is.

All in all, I do enjoy the game somewhat, but I honestly can't say I'd recommend it to anyone in it's current state. And this is coming from a kickstarter backer.

I hope they fix the issues with the game soon, because I did not sign up for another fail like 'the one that did not happen', TDR 2000.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Now when final version is out, I review C:R again.

TL:DR If you have decent computer and don't mind dated graphics, C:R is great game.

Before you judge game, remember, it is budget game.

Like many reviewers stated, performance is bad. Usually bottle neck is CPU. Game is very CPU heavy. There are some reasons why it is so heavy.

Engine is dated.
Game engine is actually based on same BRender engine which original games used. Of course it is undergone numerous rewrites, but nonetehles it is old. If you look Stainless games catalog, it is never before used any bigger modern game before C:R. Multicore support is poor, so prosessors with less cores, but more clock speed gets better FPS than prosessors with many cores and low clock speed.

Content of game is oversized in relation to engine.
Polycount of car's is almost twice as much as WreckFest's car's. Textures are HUGE! But these are not reasons why frame rates are low. Game is not really very GPU heavy. Only things that matter in GPU, is DX11 support and amount of VRAM. DirectX11 support because game uses some DX11 features, if your card doesn't support DX11 it is under minimum specs. Amount of VRAM matters because, like I said, textures are huge. You can play with 1GB VRAM card, but 1GB is absolute minimum. Don't expect texture quality be very good if you have only 1GB VRAM, but it is completely playable. Cheaper graphics card performs well as long as it supports DX11 and have enough video memory.

Why content is oversized? Stainless wanted to make triple A like game, but got only indie budget, it is due to their megalomania. Also game engine is developed alongside with content creation, artist didn't know what quality to aim. Apparently they aimed too high.

But biggest reason for low framerates is:

IT IS CARMAGEDDON!

Yea, concept of Carmageddon is very resource heavy. Openworld maps, crash physics, hundreds of pedestrians, lots of breakable things.

Not invidually any of these are alone reason, but because they are all included. Optimization is not poorly done, concept os Carmageddon just makes some optimzation techniques impossible to use.

GTA have big open world maps, much bigger than size of C:R. But it uses map streaming, that is not possible in Carma because POWERUPS. More specifially repulsificators. You know that classic powerup, first time introduced in Carmageddon 2, that generates spring from users car and hit any nearby opponent, ped or object, causing them to fly through the air. Because repulsificators can throw you or your opponent through map almost instantly, map streaming is not possible. There is no time to load and unload map parts, their must exist all time.

C:R have peds. GTA too, but in GTA peds spawns randomly and disappears when you can't see them. In Carma this is not possible because peds have fixed amount and places. If peds would spawn in Carma, it would make ped hunting and powerup called ''peds shown on map'' reduntant. So all peds exists all time, of course they are freezed when you can't see them but still they are all time loaded in memory.

If any other developer would make game like Carmageddon, they would change those two things. But Stainless wanted to keep loyal for their original vision. And if they would have chosen otherwise and cut those things, it would'nt be same game anymore. I rather take less FPS than Carma without powerups or ped hunting.

That is enough for performance, let's review gameplay because that is where this game shines.

Handling

If you ask me handling is great. It feels like first Carma's handling but improved. Sure car handles sluggish and there is not much grip, but that is way it always been. It is not purely arcade, actually it has very detailed car physics simulation. It is detailed enough, so you can do everything what you can do with real cars. If you want to powerslide, you just don't pull handbrake car drifts as long as you pull it, but you need to conuter steer, push accelerator like in real life.

If you get frustated with handling, you are playing game wrong. If you miss head on with opponent, do it with style. Don't park your car in the middle of the road, and start crying why this handling is so bad, why world is so cruel that you didn't managed to kill opponent. Instead of that, just throttle more, use direction indicator as a ramp, fly through the air, hit the apartment house, bounce from wall, fall on the lamppost, watch how lamppost crushes pedestrians when it collapses, laugh manically, repair you car and repeat.

Powerups

There are many powerups in Carmageddon. Powerup system is not very well balanced, but it doesn't matter. If somebody wreck you with powerups just do same for him. Carmageddon is not about fair play, use every dirty trick from your catalogue to kill opponents.

Some powerups from game:

Electro ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• Ray, which electrifies all nearby pedestrians.
Ave Banana, which bends car to banana.
Repulsificator, comes in three flavours, opponet, pedestrian, object. Spring that strongly pushes anything nearby.

And my favourite; ANVIL LAUNCHER. What other game let's you to throw thousands of pounds of heavy anvil toward your opponent. It is one of the most satisfying way to kill opponent, because it is entirely physic based. It destroys everything in it's path. It shortens APC (Which is overpowered car) about meter when it hits for APC.

Early Acces review:
If possible, more surrealistic, violent and insane than first two Carmas. Takes atmosphere of original, crash physics of C2 and take them new level. Sense has no place In Carma world. Drivers crash trough the windshield, cars drives and repairs themselves, there is weird power ups, bad humour, and in general, bad taste. This comic pretty much sums everything it is:
http://www.carmageddon.com/sites/default/files/comic/eng/ep3/index.html

Only con is it runs pretty poor. You need very good PC if you you want play max-settings. I hope they can optimize it lot before final release. My PC strugles even everything on low. Also it's not very stable, crashes a lot and other little bugs. But those are Pre-Alpha things.
