reviewText:
Early Access Review

This will be updated by patch to patch when possible

I dont like rating games in early access but i will put my thoughts out there first of all i grew up playing this game when i was younger it was one of my first ever pre order games back then you had to stand out the front of local video store glad to see it coming back.

Now down to the game well first of all i will warn you thr Stainless game intro is extremely loud i advise you to turn down the sound until it passes.

The game itself is extremely early access with only freeplay avaliable at this point in time and all cars are around 60% complete give or take same with tracks there are four variations

There are option for carrea mode and multiplayer but they are not avaliable yet the menus are rather hard to navigate around i think due to not all options avaliable and colors used.

gameplay is good so far but there is some performance issue's such as needing to set graphics to low to prevent lag the lag seems to happen with AI around and can crash the game and drop frames to 20 FPS at times

I love the fact they have tried to keep it original as possible i just hope they dont censor it to much for Australian market the handiling is ok could use bit of adjusting i used keyboard i will try with controller later

Overall its worth buying early if your a die hard fan but if you want the full game experince i think you will need to wait a little while longer

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Reminds me of Carmageddon 2, because it was lagging too, when I played it for the first time (software mode, no 3D accelerator). Of course, my system is a low end one, with integrated HD4000 video card, but I'm happy it runs at all.
Levels: I hate snow-ish levels and ones that has a lot of water in them, but the countryside one is amazing. It's a remake of second or third map from Carmageddon.
Cars: pretty decent line up for start, hoping for 10 of more opponents in a race in final version.
Controls: some keys were moved, so I suggest to look at key bindings before getting into the game.
Can't wait to play this game on full speed, because I just couldn't get the real feeling of physics and how they relate to 2 previous games.
And one thing that I missed the most (besides exploding barrels) - spin tires button.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EDITED AFTER BETA LAUNCH:

Game is heading terrific, old Carma feeling with a lot of new sauce. New career modes, multiplayer, customizacion for the cars and some kind of rpg-leveling for your character, hidden extras... I'm so excited the new implementations game has had in this beta thet my hype is off the record trying out everything.

Now the bad parts, as expected game perfomance is sluggish in my high end rig, bugs like car dissapearing in the map or your car being destroyed for nothing, and the most important problem for me right now is the AI of pedestrians and oponents alike that needs serious tuning up. Nothing serious and things that you would expect in Beta stage of the game.

If you were holding to buy it because alpha, now its very enjoyable, but expect some bugs and perfomance issues along with lots of old school carma fun.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


First, this is pre-alpha so not near to finished product. Keep in mind if you buy this right now yoou're buying a severe cut and bug loaded game.

Second, BUY THIS, MOAR PEOPLE I think will speed up the full release of this GEM amazing game. I deeply HATE race games, but classic Carma is my most played game of all time, always have time to go back and relax stumping people and stuff.
Best is they took all the good ideas from the first one, saved the mechanics and the amazing physics this game had(I was playing the same level I used to on the first one in ten minutes to adapt myself and was far from enough) and added pretty cool ideas.

The scenarios, beautiful mechanics, trains moving, containers falling from sky, flapping doors to kill pedestrians, new specials mechanic... Everything is amazing and give me good feelings about this game future.

Thank you for bringing this back how it deserves Stainless people!!!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fan of the original Carmageddon games? Then you will love this!
The game is still in Alpha and very much in development, but it is massively playable and enjoyable.
The graphics are amazing, using some great lighting and physics, it still has that same spark the original games have. The cars still feel like they are weighty and heavy, crashes and smashes are now even more incredible with all manner of car body parts flying off all over the place. Cops are menaces, they like to tear into the player, adding more challenge.
The original mode Classic Carma is one you will be familar with, 3 ways to win, Race, Crush, Splat (Race - Checkpoint racing, Crush - Waste all Oppponents, Splat - Kill all Pedestrians), more game modes are in the Menu but not integrated into the game - what? You expect all features to be read in Alpha?
The game is fantastic with a choice of classic racers and modes so far - I am a hardcore Carma fan and this is fantastic -
Buy It NOW!!!
Splatter Bonus!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You know what I hate? When a game developer re-releases a classic from my childhood and ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•izes a wonderful gem.

Stainless didn't do this with Carmageddon. Having clocked in an uncountable amount of hours in the Carma series, I can say with certainty (even after a mere 30 mins of playing) they stayed true to the original!

The maps, sounds, cars, peds - everything is spot on. I always dreamed about a modern-day Carmageddon and now it's here. While the game is in early access and buggy, you can tell many people put a lot of work, love and time into this awesome game.

Thank you Stainless for resurrecting and improving upon one of PC gaming's greatest titles!

reviewText:
I grew up playing the original and Reincarnation doesn't dissapoint.  I'm happy they fixed a lot of the optimization issues (although I do get the occasional frame drop in a couple of the levels), and the load times are not bad at all anymore.

Cons
-I haven't found a multiplayer game that I could join yet: either someone has different mods on or there are no games at all (this game would ROCK if tons of people were playing online)
-Occasional frame drop as mentioned above and I doubt many could run it on full settings
-Menus and replay feature are a little clunky but still work fine

Pros
+Much of the same Camageddon fun from the original games
+Upgrades of fun and familiar tracks, cars, driver, power-ups, and power-downs
+ULTRA VIOLENCE
+New game modes are a ton of fun (ped chase is awesome)

All in all, this game is a blast to play.  Just like the original games it's the little moments that keep you coming back... like that moment where you and your rival are racing from opposite directions to get the last ped point in ped chase and at the last second you use your anvil launcher and fire through the ped, killing him and it continues on to wreck your rival, then the map ends with you as the winner and accross the bottom reads MY GOD... ITS FULL OF GIBS" :D Priceless.

7/10 - Would rate higher if we could get more people playing this game!  GIB PEOPLE

reviewText:
If you've played the first two Carmageddons, this game is very much in the same vein.  It feels most similar to Carma 2.  Many of the old opponents and their cars are back, plus a few new ones.  The powerups include most of the previous ones plus some new ones--some are very helpful, some harmful, some just silly.

I never made it through TDR 2000 because for some reason it felt 'off'; fortunately, Reincarnation feels the same as the originals.

There are other several other nods to the first two in the series:  the action replay recorder is there, multiplayer includes LAN, the Fear Factory theme song, the dismembered hand for a cursor (though it no longer drips blood), some of the same sound effects, etc.

I've only purchased the game recently post-Update 2, which addressed a lot of performance issues.  Performance for me has been good, generally smooth with only occasional stutters when there are a lot of effects on screen.  Running on ~2.5 year old components.

There are a few differences:  in a section, instead of three regular maps, there will be one regular map (crash, lap, or kill peds) and then two maps with different goals.  You don't need to win or to play all three, just earn enough credits to unlock the next section.

Upgrades are now done by tokens found on maps, and then upgrade must be unlocked through progress.

Besides career mode and multiplayer, there is a free mode where you set the parameters (maps, starting location, number of laps etc)  This is a welcome addition.

Overall, it is the same over-the-top action and silliness.  Oh, and now there are dancing cows.

If you want to play a car game where you do something other than make laps, or are looking for a demolition derby game, give this a try!
voteText: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
After the lastest update, I feel like I need to revise my old review.

I previously had some problems with running the game, mostly just stable framerate. The last update gave a huge jump in performance that made it so I could enjoy the game more. I got to give credit to the dev team on listening to complaints from the community about optimization, so thanks for that.

Now, the game itself.

It feels like a carmageddon game through and through honestly. It has a fresh coat of paint, as well as some of the best mechanics and quirks from the first 2 games. I do feel that the cars physics could be improved upon, as well as a little more optimization for the blood spray and smoke effects.

7/10

reviewText: I was a fan of the Carmageddon series ever since I got to play the demo of the first game in the series back in 1997. The Death Race 2000 inspired racing game" was the most fun "driving" experience I ever experienced on PC. The game's sequel
recommended: was highly regarded an improvement in every category (though I personally liked the first game more due to the better car design). The third game in the series was developed by a different company and was widely regarded as the worst game in the series.\n\nThere hasn't been a new Carmageddon game since the year 2000
hoursPlayed: and that's a long time to wait. Well
voteText: the wait is officially over with Carmageddon: Reincarnation. The game was once again developed by Stainless
helpfulPercent: who were responsible for the first two games
votesHelpful: after a successful Kickstarter campaign.\n\nLet it be known that I was reluctant to buy this game until now due to the horrid optimization it suffered from since its release. The game's frame rate used to drop below 30fps even on high end PC's. Those issues
votesTotal: as of the latest update
votesFunny: are no longer relevant (for the most part). The game runs smoothly 99% of the time
commentsCount: though it still has a hickup here and there. I also had the game crash on me one time
column16: but that's the worst thing I had to experience with this game.\n\nOn top of the optimization
column17: the game also has an issue of (very) long loading times. It takes 1-3 minutes for a level to load. Considering how most matches in this game tend to end in about 10 minutes
column18: that's quite a long time to wait for a game with graphics that won't impress anyone in the year 2015.\n\nSo why am I recommending this? Well
column19: this game is fun. VERY FUN
column20: even. It is the most fun I had with a "racing game" since I don't even know when. The game captures the essence of the first two games perfectly
column21: with (sort of) updated graphics.\n\nEach "race" can be completed via several methods. You can either actually race (which almost nobofy ever does)
column22: you can kill all of the random pedestrians
column23: which can be found spread up in some truly bizzare locations in the various open world (ish) maps the game offers
column24: or you can do what most people do in this game - wreck the competition. Wrecking
column25: killing pedestrians and completing racing checkpoints reward you with "money" that can be used to repair your car or unlock new things in the career mode. On top of that
column26: the level has various powerups that can be collected and used to help you with your car wrecking
column27: pedestrian killing habits. Some are quite straightforward
column28: such as an afterburner
column29: while others are quite bizzare.\n\nThe damage effects on the car are quite impressive and look especially cool when you repair your car mid-game. Pieces can fall off your car
column30: which will affect the way your car performs
column31: and repairing the car will have those pieces reattach themselves back on it.\n\nThe game is still getting support from the developer

reviewText: I'm writing this review on 11/1/2015 after the second post release patch.  As you can see by the number of hours I have in this game that I've found it very enjoyable, however when it was first released near the end of April there were serious performance issues with the game.  Since the game was initially released Stainless has been working hard to fix the problems.  They released an initial patch  on August 25th that increased performance quite a bit but simplified the damage system somewhat.  On October 29th Stainless released a second patch which increases performance again, increases graphic fidelity and brings back the original damage system.  The game is finally how it should have been upon initial release and Stainless will continue working on it to make it perform even better as well as release new content and features for the game.

reviewText:
As of the latest patch, the game has finally become the title it was supposed to be. At its recent state, I can recommend the game to not only to carma fans but also to new people to the franchise. The game now runs perfectly well and is mostly bug-free. The game offers replayability and is more than fun to play.

Pros:
+Entertaining
+Runs smooth (finally)
+Single maps have much content and variance
+Awesome destruction modeling for the cars
+Fitting music
+Price

Cons:
-Driven by the player, some vehicles don't serve a purpose and are outclassed in every way when compared to other vehicles
-If played on easy settings and as straightforward as possible, the game is relatively short

So-So:
/Map numbers are limited and different races take part in the same maps. This shouldn't come as a surprise to people familiar with the previous games
/Plot-seeking players should reconsider


All in all, I'd like to congratulate Stainless for the effort of finishing the game, albeit late. I've played through all the Carma games (even the dreadful) and the series has always had a warm place in my heart. Now I can rest at ease knowing that the developer did not abandon the latest spectacle's development after the initial unoptimized and bug-ridden release. While the game lacks some elements typical to a game, like a plot, it delivers hours of entertainment where you can not only win the race by being the first to the finish but also making sure the other competitors don't make it that far.

After the latest patch, I'd rate the game 10/10 because it finally runs smoothly on other devices besides supercomputers and because it does not try to be anything it is not and excels at what it is. Nice job Stainless!

reviewText: I'll be honest, props to the devs that managed to keep the Carmageddon feeling practically intact with passion and I respect that, but this is also my biggest issue with the game. The game feels nice if you have carmageddon nostaliga (carmastalgia). It will probably fill that void, but that's it... Recommended mostly for Carmageddon die hard fans. Nothing outstanding, nothing new under the sun basically, true that the game looks somehow prettier now and it runs better. Nonetheless I got bored of it pretty quickly. The Environments feel and look boring, there are a few new cars, but basially just the handful few that are actually pleasant to drive, exactly like in the old game. A few new gameplay modes that are pretty boring too. And the worst things are powerups, one might expect some new interesting ones, but no... Developers could have made a lot of new improvements since the Carmageddon franchise certainly still has a lot of potential. I'm sorry but re-making the same old game with new textures and effects won't cut it. Carmageddon deserves more than a reincarnation, deserves a revolution :)\n\n

reviewText:
The recent patch finally made C:R playable on recommended hardware specs. The loading times are still pretty bad, graphics look dated, but it's Carmageddon.
There's no other game like it.

Compared to the older titles it has some new (but also some of the old ones) powerups, cars, tracks, etc.
The driving model is still floaty and imprecise, but the carnage and fun of murdering pedestrians and AI drivers is still there.

If you're looking for a newer Carmageddon 2. Then you've found it. If you want GTA, Driver, or GRID, then I'm afraid you won't be having much fun here.

reviewText:
(Posted after patch v1.1.0.7470 was released.)

As a long-time Carmageddon fan, I was incredibly excited when Reincarnation was announced.  Once the game was released, however... there were lots of game-breaking bugs - in my case, lots of CTDs, which made the game nearly unplayable for longer than an hour.  However, the latest patch fixed just about every major and minor problem that this game had at launch, so I can now happily recommend it!  Why?  Read on...

GRAPHICS
Compared to racing games that were released over the last two years, these graphics are fairly simple in comparison, so I expect this game would run really smooth on mid-range computers.  If you played Carmageddon TDR 2000, you may even think they didn't do much, graphically-speaking.  That said, the vehicle damage physics is really good, with deformations, all manners of car chunks falling off based on what hits you, and peds fall apart is various juicy ways.

MUSIC & SOUND
The soundtrack is fairly small - you'll hear all the tracks at least once within the first hour of gameplay.  In addition, the tracks used on the main menu are the same ones used when actually playing - they don't stop, in fact, so as you make your selections and load up a stage, the tracks just seemlessly continue.  You may want to consider adding your own custom tracks so what you hear doesn't go stale.  As for sound effects, they're a pleasure to hear when you crunch a ped against a wall, or use your door to pop into someone's face.  The crunching of your car against metal and other obstacles are nice, but nothing outstanding.

GAMEPLAY & REPLAYABILITY
I managed to blast through the campaign mode (it's how you unlock stages, cars, and other unlockables) in just under 5 hours - assuming you're focused solely on completing all the chapters.  There's a lot to do in each chapter, and the first stage in each chapter has three different ways to complete them: kill all opponents, complete all laps, or kill all peds.  There are over 15 vehicles to unlock, plus unlockable skins and rims... so yeah, you'll be busy!  And you'll want to unlock the vehicles - the starter vehicles are awesome (who doesn't like the Eagle?), but some of what you can unlock are downright sick, from a bulldozer to a faux-Delorean!  If you think it's just you and the other crazy drivers on the road, you are wrong: the police are out to stop you at any cost as well.

All vehicles can be upgraded (weapons, armor, and speed) with upgrade coins that you find scattered amongst the stages, something I'm not the biggest fan of - I'd rather use the credits you rack up on a stage as a source of currency as well.  Granted, they added a way of buying items on-demand now, using the credits you earn when killing peds and drivers (I've only used this ONCE, as I think it makes accomplishing objectives much easier).

Lastly, the items.  There are tons of items that can be picked up during a race - some impact the entire stage for a limited time  (Jupiter Gravity!, Pinball Mode), some affect you for a limited time (Instant Handbrakes), and others are usable on-demand a limited number of times (Have a Banana Ray, Ped Vacuum, Earthquake Bomb).  Some items are amazing, others are designed to wreck your life, but it's a healthy mix, and I've enjoyed using all that the game gives you to make the lives of others a living hell!

CONCLUSION
Reincarnation has a fair amount to offer, from the newbie to the Carmageddon veteran.  It's not graphically amazing, but I'd like to think that we all don't only care about graphics - it's all about the gameplay, and Reincarnation delivers what you'd expect from the bloody series.  I hope that we see a legit expansion pack in the future with more stages and vehicles, as one can probably unlock the majority of the game in under 10 hours of gameplay.  Is it worth your money?  At full price, I believe it's worth more than the $60 you'd spend on most AAA games.  If you catch this when on-sale, DEFINITELY pick it up!  If you've ever dreamed of using your car as a weapon of mass destruction, or play a violent driving game that doesn't hold back, you can't do much better than Reincarnation!

reviewText:
Back in the Old Days a Game Called Carmageddon Splatted onto our screens and into our hearts.
This is a pretty faithful reboot of the days gone by.

That said, it hasn't aged well, the game still feels unfinished, and takes an ages to load even from an SSD.

As a Backer I am disappointed in this game, it could have been so much more.

The new race types are a nice change, but the game balance seems rather broken, cars are simultaneously too fragile and too tough, sometimes a light bump is all they need to explode, other times cars can take massive impacts, mines and mortars and cheap kicking.

Speaking of power ups, they are just many flavours of the same thing with cosmetic differences, and most are pretty useless.

R.I.P Carmagedon, see you in the next life.

reviewText:
Carmageddon is finally back - and it's just like old times!

Smashing opponents into walls, running over pedestrians and utilising an arsenal of over-the-top, wacky weapons has never felt better. reviewText:
For those of your unfamiliar with the Carmageddon series, the premise is simple: race outrageous vehicles in courses filled with pedestrians and other breakable objects.  The general goal is to complete all the checkpoints, mow down all the pedestrians, or destroy all of the opposing vehicles.  Outrageous stunts and kills are rewarded appropriately.

C:R is a modern update of the original, and arguably the best, Carmageddon.  All of the vehicles and courses in the C:R were inspired" by the first game.

But
date: like every sequel to the original

reviewText:
i loved carmageddon 1 + exp and 2, they were fun to play, 3/tdr 2000 was... well the worst piece of trash ever in comparison, boring levels, boring cars, couldnt see the difference between driving 40kph or 400kph. pass the bomb was a bit amusing in multiplayer but thats about it. now i didnt keep myself informed of reincarnation after it got kickstarted, but what i half expected was, the return of some golden oldies racers and their cars as well as a heap of new ones, an improved and possibly more advanced upgrade system.

what i got: only old racers and their cars(and only a few), instead of buying cars after you wreck them you automatically get one select car per race if you wreck it, unlike the previous games where races had random racers these races seem to have predermined racers, the money you earn is exclusively for unlocking more races it seems, same old APO upgrade system only with limited points and you need to unlock upgrades by completing new races(its not really negative or positive objectively speaking but i dont like it personally), otis p jivefunks car is not the cool one from the earlier games, ive only played with red eagle so i cant say anything about high speeds but it looks like youre doing 20kph when youre doing 200kph, and tires seem to be made of lubricated ice.

as far as the technical aspects: car details are quite good, graphics are bad at max and terribad at the level i have to play so it doesent drop below 40fps(im currently on a nvidia 690 wich runs almost all newer games ive played at max without issues).

all in all, like tdr 2000 this doesent feel like a driving game at all, not much thought was given to the actual driving part, seems like all resource has been devoted to level creation and the car damage system. the speedometer might as well be a random number generator, chances are it would show the right speed at some point that way atleast. i didnt expect gran turismo with violence or something, but i atleast expected something like the old carma games(tdr 2000 not included). this is game is just cashing in on their fame.... hearing fear factory - zero signal when i started the game was damn nice though. but with respect to the old games i cant recommend this. ill stick to playing carmageddon 1 and 2 every couple of years as usual.

reviewText:
The game I have been waiting for! I loved the old series and spent many an hour playing them. This is a great homage to the original series and really fun, a great new modern take on the whole thing. It's fast, fun and is one of the only recent games I have played through all the way to the end. Well worth the money I paid (¬£19).

Multiplayer is a blast when you get enough people together but sometimes it's quite difficult to find other players that are online. In the forums you can add others to you friends list and people will play in groups from there.

I have watched the game improve from alpha, it has had a few performance issues for some; for me it has been fairly good all the way through. I won't say its an amazing technical achievement performance wise, because it's not - it's a fairly heavy beast specs wise. Now the game runs fine for me like I say but I have a mid-high end pc and it runs 60fps  v sync locked all the time.

reviewText:
Abysmal facsimile of a great title
-----------------------------------

As a long-term player of the Carmageddon series, of which I‚Äôve been a huge fan for more than 15 years, I looked forward to this game with eager anticipation, however, I was extremely disappointed.

What I can only imagine is un-optimised code means this game takes much too long to load (both on start-up and the individual levels), which is a problem that doesn‚Äôt happen with any other games I have.  I had hoped this issue would be down to the fact that it was in beta when I first got it, however, with the full release, it‚Äôs still just the same.

Then, once you‚Äôve waited for it to load, you‚Äôre greeted with a game which, whilst graphically adequate, is logically unappealing; gravity and momentum seem to work completely at random, meaning you‚Äôre forced to guess what your vehicle is going to do when you attempt to change direction or velocity (this doesn‚Äôt appear to affect the computer-controlled opponents making combat frustrating), and damage to the computer-controlled opponents doesn‚Äôt seem to mean anything (cars with only 2 wheels left are faster and more manoeuvrable than your car is).  This means it‚Äôs difficult to race, and impossible to engage in combat effectively, and those, for me at least, are the point of a Carmageddon game.

As someone who still maintains an old laptop running Windows 98 specifically so I can play old school games, Carmageddon 2 included, I have to point out that I‚Äôm still playing Carmageddon 2 after 16 years, whereas this new version is consigned to my ‚Äòno thanks‚Äô list after less than 16 hours.

Verdict:  Not worthy of the Carmageddon name.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of v0.9 (Beta):
It's Carmageddon. No, it's THE Carmageddon. The one that's we've been waiting for so long.
It's fun, it's brutal, it has lots of cars, tracks, places and powerups. And of course lots of pedestrians to run over.
If you ever played the old Carmageddons, this one feels almost exactly the same way. Although it does have several nice additions in comparison to old ones. Including cool repair animation with parts that has fallen off flying back to your car and killing peds on the way. And of course modding support - a very important thing that will undoubtedly keep the game alive for years after release.

On the downside: the game is poorly optimized. I could barely get consistent 40 fps with everything on lowest settings on my GTX 970. Some people with older GPUs report as little as 4-7 fps.
So, if you don't own a powerful PC, or just don't want to play with all the settings on minimum (which does not really look very impressive) - I'd suggest waiting until devs sort out the optimization.

Other than this. Well, the game's damn fun. It's a worthy successor of the series even in it's current (very) raw state.

See video for impressions of beta v0.9 here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7iUm0GkyaXs

See video for initial impressions of v0.1.3 here:
http://youtu.be/zTN0pf3QdiY

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Carmageddon Reincarnation is shaping up to be probably one of the best remakes of an old game ever. or at least one that stays very close to its original in both gameplay and feel.

The game feels like carmageddon 2 but looks like a more modern day racing game with high detail graphics and sound.
the damage system is impressive, and unlike other games with damage systems, it manages to disable and damage your vehicle without getting too much in the way.

Currently it's early access form, lacks things like career mode, and a slew of options. but it is quite playable for a bit of casual mayhem.

If the games multiplayer stacks up I could see the game becomming very popular once out of early access.

There are however some problems, being early access I have no doubt they will be fixed eventually.
currently some of the problems:
Level load times take ages even on high end systems, 2 minutes + on average.
Detail settings require a restart but it does not inform you of this.
Maxing out all settings gives horrible FPS even on a high end card.

but everything else makes up for it. I would reccommend this game to any fans of the old game, and anyone looking for some casual fun. as it stands, as long as you do not crank the detail too high the game plays smooth and feels nice.
but it is not finished and I belive in a year or so, they will have done great things.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nCarmageddon 1 & 2 are probably the games i played the most in my life, this pre alpha is so promising, capturing the old spirit of the good old ped dismemberment, dark humor and enhancing it with next gen graphics and physics, can't wait for the final release and see my life wasted away playing this for hours and hours. 243/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you loved the old ones, you'll love this one, too.

I was afraid they would screw up what made this game great in the first place by giving in to the usual remake temptations. BIGGER! BETTER! MORE EXTREME! I can't say what they have planned for the other modes which are still unavailable, but so far it's the same old single player game mechanic where you can win by racing, destroying your opponents or mowing down all the pedestrians.

The car models are pretty nice, though the environments still need a lot of work. The only glitches I've seen are an occasional pink bar on two sides of the screen when I play on my laptop. I don't have powerhouse rigs at all (GTX 770M an GTX 650) yet it runs pretty well though load times are glacial. Sometimes it takes a few minutes to load a level. Once it loads, it's fine. I haven't had any of the problems others are reporting.

I hoped they would have had more progress by now, but they have added a bunch of cars and races so I can't really complain.

Overall, I think it's on the right path and I'm glad that it finally came back.



Update May 8 2015: I've upgraded to a GTX 970 so I can only guess how much improvement was from hardware or optimization.

Runs much smoother, though there's still a fair amount of jitter.

FPS stays above 30 with maxed out settings though it can still bog down when there's a lot on the screen (like the starting line).

Load times are much improved, though still slow.

Bottom line: a worthwhile reboot that can still benefit from some optimization and balancing.

reviewText: Damn, what a disappointment this game is when it released. With the extra month, I was hoping Stainless would be able to fix the horrible optimization but they sadly didn't provide. I personally loved the original games and this game mostly plays like the originals. I don't mind the muddy graphics but I do wish they were updated along with updating the game. I find it a good game but the optimization is what overall kills it. You can have a monster rig and you're taking a chance with this game. Some people claim to run it fine but most of us over here are experiencing the worst optimized game ever. While I did find Stainless trustworthy, this game is making me cautious of them now. Oh, and if you want to know what frames I'm getting, they are 45-50 on low (and I mean the lowest you can go), medium 30 fps, high/ultra 30 fps. reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI really can't express how incredibly impressed I am about this reincarnation of the classic Carmageddon series and Stainless' ability to rekindle the spirit after so many years! Having grown up with Carmageddon 1 and 2, I have a special and rather nostalgic relationship with these games - especially towards C2, which is my favourite of the two. When I first became aware of this remake" I was of course very skeptical
date: because how often do these things really turn out great? I was wrong: Stainless has stayed 100% true to the Carmageddon legacy and already at the time of writing (if everything goes as planned) I believe this will be the best Carmageddon game ever. I have recently played the two first games and as much as I love them
recommended: the gameplay of Reincarnation is simply more entertaining and involving (I am not considering graphics here). The new power-ups are a big reason for that; for instance you can get a power-up that sucks pedestrians towards your car and one that lets your car spin around quickly destroying any pedestrians in your trajectory to mention some. In other words more imaginative ways to punish peds.\n\nMake no mistake: this is real Carmageddon material made by the same people that gave us the originals using the same philosophy as they did back then. I think they just may have pulled off a very rare feat in the gaming industry
hoursPlayed: that is making a game in a series that is better than the originals after so many years. Carmageddon: Reincarnation feels like a blend of the best things from C1 and C2 and then some more...\n\nGet it!"

reviewText:
Meant to do this sooner, as in last year after the update.

The developers have greatly improved the optimisation, stuttering has gone for me and even without SLI it runs at about 60fps at 1440p on a 980 (and to be fair, a single 980 is only barely enough for 1440p) on near maximum settings. Before I was sitting around 40ish fps with stuttering, and that was at low settings. So, it's come a long way.

It's a joy to play now, and Stainless should be credited for the improvements.


Pros:

- Really fun game. There are multiple modes, including multiplayer. The favourite is Classic Carma where you either kill all the pedestrians, wreck all the opponents, or be a boring old sod and race normally.

- Excellent damage model. Parts fly off, wheels fly off, drivers fly off. Repairing causes the parts to fly back to you. You can turn pedestrians into a cloud of blood.

- Tons of power ups that add a dynamic experience to the game, anything from low gravity to being able to blow up pedestrians.

- The classic humour from Stainless.

- Open map design, basically go where you want on the map. You're not confined to a track.

- Load times seemed to be improved too. I put it on an SSD and it cut it to about 12 seconds for a map.

- As said above, optimisation is greatly improved.


Cons:

- The cars can feel a bit 'floaty' at times, and takes some getting used to. This may be a design choice, seeing as the older Carmageddons feel similar.

- No SLI support, at least not natively (there is probably a workaround). However, with the optimisation improvements, I didn't really find it too much of a problem.

- The graphics could be better, but whether that would kill performance with the damage model I don't know. It's fine for what it is in any case. I believe they improved, but I was playing on low before and near maximum now. They're not terrible by any means, though.

- No PratCam. Not a huge issue, and was only in Carmageddon 1, but it was a nice feature.



All in all, they've greatly improved the game since the launch. It's worth buying now, especially at ¬£19.99. The game itself is just fun, doesn't take itself seriously, and is a blast to play. With the open level design, power ups and the nature of the game, each 'race' feels different, which gives the game a good amount of replayability.

So yes, it's worth buying now.



My rig:

I7 4790k @4.5GHz
16GB 2400mhz DDR3 RAM
SLi 980GTX (overclocked at that)
Running the game off of a 1TB Samsung 850 Pro SSD

reviewText:
I got mixed feelings about this game. As a 80's kid I was pretty surprised to find a new Carmageddon game.

After watching a streamer play for an hour I decided 25 euro might actually be worth the try.

I'm around 40% of the game now and 7 hours of play time, and this is what I have to say.

Is it carmageddon? Hell yeh! But nothing like the old game. This is a race game (laps, checkpoints etc) with a carmageddon flavor. It does not feel like the old game one bit. I enjoyed Carmageddon 1,2 and TDR, but this is just a dissapointment.

- The handling of the cars is rediculous. It feels like you're driving on ice 24/7. Making it impossible to aim for certain objects/points.
- In the old carmageddon I would never ever finish a race by doing the laps. I would just consider it a destruction derby game and go ham on all the opponents. Here I actually find myself finishing the laps just to be done with it.
The main problem is that you do absolutely no damage!? I got level 4 upgrades and when I ram someone it feels like I'm just giving them a little bump (tried multiple cars). On the other side if they hit me, I find myself without wheels, bodywork and basically down to my chassis or wrecked..
-  As it seems you don't have enough damage to wreck cars by smashing into them, it feels like powerups are the only way to wreck some opponents. Hunting the map for powerups is frustrating and takes away the fun of the game.
- The maps sometimes are just plainly annoying. Small bridges, water, bumps etc. It's a pain in the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• with the handling of the cars. Not to mention the sometimes countless bodies on the ground making it impossible to drive straight. Is that annoying in general? Not really, however when you have to cross a small section and it's littered with bodies + the obnoxious handling of the cars, ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• yeh it is.

It ain't all bad. The game does bring a portion of fun and a smile to your face.

-The new game modes like checkpoint and pedestrian hunting are great fun. I would love to try that with a group of friends.
- The nostalgia of playing carmageddon.

To sum it up.
I would not recommend this game the state it's in now. It lacks the pure carmageddon taste. I think it does have the potential to become one. However if this is the final release, then that does make me sad.

I will finish the game, to make me feel like I didn't waste my money completely and then play C1,2 or TDR since I bought the full pack. For the old fans, wait untill the game drops down to a price range of 10 or less. Then it would have been worth it in the current state of the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros
+ Many different cars to choose from, each with their own unike attributes like speed and strength , giving very amusing and sterotypicial diving styles , I was grinning from ear to ear the first time i got into the dragster and failed to get it around the first corner :-) . The faster sport syle cars are great for ridge racer style drifting, and the heavier bruisers are great for smashing opponents into walls.

+ 4-5 Large open world maps with many different possible routes. The maps look great, there is even 2 arena style destruction debry maps which really caught my eye.

+ The Gory sarcastic carma comedy is there

Cons

- No multiplayer yet
- Ai is very weak  , even on the hardest setting i could win every race no problems, i remember carma being hard.
- Weapons need tuned and balanced , some seem very overpowered
- Seem to have infinite money for repairs and respawns

Overall this game has potential , if it gets a balanced multiplayer, an upgraded ai some optimasation and minor bug fixs, it should be good to go. For the price i paid ¬£19.99 it sucks not to have multiplayer and i would rate this product 4/10 in its current state.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me be the *probably not last to say*, that this is a refreshing game, even pre-alpha, crashing left and right. To be able to use FULL KEYBOARD CONTROLS. I grew up a keyboard jockey in the gaming era of the 1990's starting with games like commander keen, doom, wolf 3d. This runs fantastic even on my core 2 quad /w 8gb ram. BUT, win 8 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•es about being out of memory, so i'm guessing that there are quite a few memory leaks in the game, but being pre-alpha, that is perfectly ok.

After actually playing the first map, and unlocking the rest of the game. I feel compelled to add more to my review.

A great deal of sounds are reused, which holds to the carma theme, notably the tire squeals, listen carefully, you will here it. And the checkpoint, i think the same dude was used, sounds the same, but older.

I focused on playing Beef Curtains, and i noticed A LOT of things, both new and old. The park map, is the same one used in Carma 1, the old track is now dirt, the loop is still there, so is the jump from hell, the coastal track is still asphalt. My point is this, they took the old map, UPDATED IT, like time had passed froom Carma 1 to the new game. Playing it is a whole new map, but i found nods to the old map there. I believe the other maps may be the same way, with new maps.

Things i've noticed about how detailed this game is now, and how i hope it will be once done.

Engines:  if you take their hood off, you can see the engine torquing as it would in a normal car, even changes RPM same way.

Car Parts: You can rip entire axles off cars, you can even rip cars in two with the plow, which has a back up beeper, Nice Touch!

Drivers: You can now kill the driver independantly of the car. I have knocked Stella out of her car, and run her over, which got me the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• announcement

The cows: they go moo, like a dude is voicing the moo, groovy peds makes the cows dance,  and you can now carry peds a distance before killing them, which makes for some creative ways to kill people.

I do like all the nods to all 3 previous carma games, the inclusion of power ups from all 3 of them, and the people hopping around on one leg, from TDR 2000.

A couple of gripes however:

Motion Blur : Seems it would tax even the most advanced of graphics boards, can be turned off, so not a real gripe, but interesting nonetheless
Keyboard Assignment : We cannot change keys as of yet, something to implement for the future
Prat Cam : Please give us back the Prat Cam. Nothing is more gratifying than to see Max Damage hit a person with the roof of his car while he is saying Mommy!"

The main problem with this pre-alpha is memory consumption
date: i get windows is out of memory twice an hour. and that is a clean boot right into the game
recommended:
with 8GB ram.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Carmageddon Reincarnation is looking good! The Beta release is a massive step-up from the Pre-alpha. It's got the feel of the old games, with physics that would almost be at home in a proper racing game. Crash damage is excellent, and while the peds are far from GTA quality, they do seem a lot better than in the pre-alpha.

One thing that made Carmageddon 1 and 2 so great was the thought that went into the designs of both the tracks and cars. Thankfully Reincarnation is no different! All the cars are highly detailed, both the remakes and new designs, and each has it's own wacky design features. As for the tracks, you can spend hours simply exploring them. Most of the maps are large, with tons of hidden areas. The remakes of some popular Carmageddon 1 locations create a sense of nostalgia, but achieve it without looking old and outdated.

The only real criticism is the game performance, an issue that the developers are well aware of and are trying their hardest to fix. I found it considerably better than the pre-alpha, although it has some way to go. Loading times are long, and there were a few framerate drops, most notably at the start of a race. The coastal level also had a tendency to crash my video card drivers until I turned the graphic quality down. The majority of the time, it ran fairly smoothly though. As long as you have a decent system, it's certainly a very playable and enjoyable game. Considering it also includes the previous games in the series, it's good value for money too. I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
How these guys can sell this for 32.99 CDN is totally beyond me.

There may well be a decent game here but you'll never know it due to the horrific performance issues.

FTR, I'm running a 5960X, 3 GTX 980s, 32GB RAM and RAID0 SSDs.

Upon loading the game, I immediately noticed that it was only using one GPU, this is not uncommon with indie games and I don't have a major issue with the lack of SLI support outside of AAA titles so off we go.

Set my video options (maxed with the exception of DOF) and jumped into career mode.

With 'vsync' on I was stuck at 30 FPS which was not going to work in a fast paced game like this so I turned 'vsync' off and enabled it through NVinspector.

Restarted the game, 'vsync' working but now, the game is sitting at around 45 FPS (Fluctuating wildly with inexplicable drops) and for a game that looks as lackluster as this game does, 45 FPS isn't going to cut it either.

I turned off 'bloom' and 'AA', exited the game, enabled FXAA through NVinspector, restarted the game and now we are at between 47 and 50 FPS (still fluctuating, with random drops into the 20s).

Then, there's the loading times :ugh:

I've seen people trying to justify this on the forums and I'm sorry, there is no justification. The loading times are absolutely ridiculous. I do not believe I own any other games that take as long as this game does to load. It's an absolute pisstake.

I can't stress enough that this game does not look very good and that is OK, there are plenty of games that don't look like Crysis 3 but are  far better due to the actual gameplay.

This is not one of them.

Granted I have only played for an hour or so but I don't see that there is a lot more to it, and with the performance being as terrible as it is, I don't really have a lot of incentive to find out.

I want to be fair, so for those who are willing to play at 720P w/ low detail, maybe there is some fun to be had here.

I try to cut indie games some slack because I do realize that they are quite often being developed by a small team but since this is not the first game in this series and since performance has been criticized on the forums for quite some time, I quite simply cannot recommend this to anyone.

The game needs a massive overhaul, you need only look at something like 'Road Redemption' to see this type of game done right.

reviewText:
Okay so, I'm a long time Carmageddon fan, and after playing the game for a good amount in pre-alpha, beta, and now full release, I can safely say it's a lot of fun, but disappointingly, only if you can run it. I barely can, and I'm running on an i7something and a GTX670whatever. I wouldn't really have a problem with turning some settings down if the game looked better.

Honestly, the dated looking graphics don't really bother me at all. I'll happily play old games with old graphics, and new games with dated graphics, but when a game looks 8 years old, and plays like a game from 8 years in the future, you've got a problem. I strongly suggest looking into whether you'll be able to achieve a decent FPS, or waiting until maybe some optimisation happens. I'm concerned that it won't though because honestly, it feels a bit like the game was released because they ran out of resources and time rather than actually finished it.

Fortunately, turning the graphics down a bit results in 50-60fps for me, so I can actually play the game without a struggle. Once that happens, it's great fun. There's a lot of fun things to do, lots going on, and it feels just like classic Carmageddon games. The new modes are nice, though the AI doesn't really know too well how to best reach some objectives, for example a target ped on a rooftop.

Overall, I recommend the game, but unfortunately I can only base that on gameplay alone.

Please please optimise this game better. It has so much potential to be a great community and is otherwise so much fun, if only more people could run it!
voteText: 34 of 64 people (53%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D9EexkMgiKE
Carmageddon Reincarnation is the sequel to the original Carmageddon game from 20 years ago.  It was first Kickstarted back in 2012, then landed on Steam Early Access, and is now available for the official final release.  But was it worth the long wait and is this reboot better than the original?  Let's take a look at Carmageddon Reincarnation in this First Impression review.

Carmageddon is known for car combat and unrelenting violence.  It was one of the original games that gave you points for arbitrarily running over pedestrians and crashing into your opponents.  Reincarnation has several different modes but they are all basically variations on racing to checkpoints while simultaneously running over pedestrians and bashing your opponents.  Doing these two tasks plus running overall barrels provides you with credits that you use to purchase weapons and repair your vehicle.  There's three ways to win: finish the race first, wreck your opponents vehicles, or kill all the peds.

The game is basically just mayhem and twisted fun.  If you're expecting a straight racer, you're in the wrong place.  You'll find enemies driving in the wrong direction just to run you over.  Racing freely around the map without feeling like you have to play seriously can be a lot of fun.  I find myself getting lost in demolition derby type moments with other cars.  And then straying off course when I want to mow down a big batch of pedestrians.

The weapons are ridiculous.  Some of them will make pedestrians fly into the air or start dancing arbitrarily.  Then you have weapons that will launch your opponents or leave mines on the course for them.  Another cool feature is the damage model.  It's incredibly detailed and it's amazing to watch your car start fraying and fall apart and then come back together again as you hit repair.  The soundtrack is also pounding heavy metal that's 100 percent suitable for this action.

Those are the fun parts of Carmageddon, but let's talk about the negatives.  The performance of the game is really bad.  Initially I thought it was possibly the settings or too much multitasking on my computer, but it wasn't.  A lot of other people are complaining that they cannot hit 60 frames per second even after reducing the graphics settings.  I can run Dying Light and Shadows Of Mordor on Ultra at 60fps, but my computer struggles to hit 60 fps on medium quality in this game.  And I had some serious stuttering issues where the entire game would just pause for a second or two.  The devs have stated that the poor performance is due to the high amount of physics rendering and they are working on improvements, but this doesn't seem playable for people who are on mid range or budget gaming computers.

As far as the gameplay, it honestly seems outdated.  I want to like Carmageddon Reincarnation, but it doesn't bring anything new.  The gameplay and the levels feel like they are held too closely to the original without modernizing the action.  Racing and combat can have dull points where it seems like you just can't make the car perform the way you want it to.  Cars have a floaty feel where you will miss hitting peds and cars due to the fact that the steering lacks proper handling.  These flaws kill the fun in this otherwise cool game.  While the graphics of the car models look excellent, the models of the Peds and of the environment are lacking.

My opinion on Carmageddon is mixed.  As much as I like the idea of classic 90s style vehicle violence, I don't think it was executed well.  Actually playing the game lacks the intensity I saw in the trailers and that I anticipated for this reboot.  If you don't have a high end gaming rig, you may want to hold off until the performance issues are fixed.   Save this game for the die hard Carmageddon fans.

Positives:
Classic Car Combat And Killing
Rockin Heavy Metal Soundtrack
Great Destruction Model

Negatives:
Performance Issues
Outdated graphics
Floaty Physics
Outdated Gameplay

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It sickNs me to see stainless having to promote this master piece of game play. long haul trucking and train simulators don't go to these extents.

Wha I am trying to say is: stainless had me at C:/carma/carma.exe

Carmageddon 1 was Grand Theft Auto when Doom 2 was still being developed.

Carmageddon 2 was an attempt to give those who loved Carmagedon 1 MORE. Though I disliked Carma 2. I was Rush 2 with driving over people, or not you could just as easily be a goody goody who stuck to the race track or punished those AWEFUL death racers.

The carmageddon genre of games have ALWAYS given, the players who play them, FREEDOM. After all that is what we're paying for; that is why GTA does so well, sometimes you just want to do things you can not. GTA had shooting a hooker after she 'does' you in a car you've stolen, and Carmageddon; puts you inside of, one of many, sweet ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• cars, and lets you drive that car AS YOU WISH.

Into people, off of cliffs, through obsticles, 1000 feet into the air, ALL at 200MPH, and with this new generation of damage modeling, come crashing down into a shattered husk of former glory, and watch while the pieces snap back into position with the press of a button, and some hard earned credits, without so much as you having to pick up a wrench.

I could go on for hours about this, the fourth installment, of Carmageddon, but I don't have to. This game is THE representation of a company giving they're customers what they want, and I do not need to romance it. If you have only ever played mainstream, also-on-console, new-version-same-as-the-last-on-but-with-shinier-menus, drivle, this game will introduce you to wanting more from the people you give your money too.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As others have said, it's Carmageddon.  If you liked the original game, get this - from what I've played so far, you won't be disappointed.

If you don't know already, there's three ways to win a race:
- Take out all your opponents (they're surely gunning for you... do unto others before they do unto you, and all that...)
- Wipe every ped off the map (slower, but there's nothing like the satisfaction of this victory on a 1000+ ped map...)
- Or, well, simply run the laps... (seriously, has anyone ever won this way except just to be a completist?)

A request to Stainless: Please (pleaseplease) don't give in to any temptation to add suck to this as we move towards final release!  The fun is in the chaos and the carnage.  If we wanted missions (C2 & TDR2K) and arbitrarily low max time limits (TDR2K) we would have bought a different racing game.  Please keep the game as it was originally intended: A racing game for the chemically imbalanced!""

reviewText:
EDIT - Updated on May 22nd.

I've been playing this game extensively for 90+ hours and there's still plenty to play.
Before i go into pros and cons, i have to add that Carmageddon Reincarnation, although gone out of BETA and into GOLD, is not yet the complete experience.
It is known that the developers are working on many new never-before seen in Carmageddon features such as 2-wheeled tech, Tracked Wheel tech (the ability to add tanks in game :D), new maps, cars and car splitting.
Also being a small/medium sized studio the amount of work, they achieved in crushing bugs is phenomenal. Key features like Pinball mode, used to be huge CPU eaters (rightfully so), but not anymore! Each event in Single Player runs pretty smooth!
By the way
here's my performance report :

Game runs good on 1080p Medium Settings on a 2012 PC. i5-3470 , 8GB RAM , GTX 750Ti, Samsung SSD 120GB. Runs great" means 40-70 FPS on all times. And it is great since anything above 35FPS is enjoyable. 25-35 FPS is playable. Minor FPS drops only in Multiplayer. Single Player is great!

I played the newest build (Gold Version) for a few hours and here's what i have to say for the v.1.0 and the game in general

Pros
-Awesome sandbox maps and gameplay full of unexpected outcomes.
-One of the most detailed crushing code/physics i've ever seen in a car/driving game
-Great car models! Each car is unique with it's own parts (moving or not) and drives differently.
-Sounds and animations are hilariously stupid! Cow sounds for example always give me a good chuckle.
-Enemy car AI has improved A LOT since Alpha! I was amazed at the preciseness of the whole thing. If i'm allowed to post videos in reviews to showcase this
date:
i will.
-The performance is good and smooth now on a 2012 PC rig.

Cons
-Although i never go went lower than 30FPS on 1080p mostly on medium settings
hoursPlayed: the game could still be optimized a bit more.\n-One map feels visually empty (Icy Oil Rig).\n-Receiving and giving damage on Hard Difficulty is insane. That might or might not be a case with you (may other people found it pretty easy)
voteText: but i was getting wrecked all the time and the damage i dealt to others was not satisfactory. On lower difficulty modes it's much better.\n\nOverall this game has the best combination of physics
helpfulPercent:
fun and gameplay from all the latest driving games. Should you like Car Mayhem games i recommend this.
If you're a fan of the first Carmageddon games i can't even describe how much you'll love this game.

INITIAL REVIEW :
So far (April 5th 2014)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Weather you're new or old, Carmageddon: Reincarnation does exactly what i was hoping for in a remake of one of the franchizes that defined my childhood. Being in Pre-Alpha early access means it's quite limited now, but tickles every bone in my nostalgia sensors and does it with style.  I've been waiting for this game for many years and have enjoyed the others that came before it especially 2 and TDR 2000. If you love racing games that offer you more than just laps around a liniar track, giving you powerful and sometimes crazy powerups, running over countless people and animals and blowing up the competition, look no further. Long as i've had to wait, while it's not perfect it's everything i've hoped it would be in this stage of it's development.
9/10

EDIT:
Now that the public beta" is out and it's practically a full game i can safely say that my opinion has not faultered but grown. Load times have improved across the board (no longer takes excess of 5 minutes to load the big city map) New modes and career are a blast if a bit same-y Still a few bugs and unexpected situations here and there but it's nothing to hinder performance. Each vehicle has a unique personality that reflects that of their driver
date:
their weapons behave as they should.

My childhood squeels with glee whenever i play a new round. Everything i'd hoped it would be and i hope more comes soon.

One final note
recommended: unless you have the patience of a brain surgeon

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What can I say about Carmageddon.  The original Carmageddon came during the era of Doom and Mortal Kombat, when ultra violence and excessive blood in a game was the norm.  It came during the big 3D Card boom of the late 90's.  It was different from every other racing game out there.  Set in a sort of Deathrace 2000 future where violent criminals raced for cash on live TV and ran over any pedestrian that got in their way.

The original game has been a long time favorite of mine, as well as it's sequel.  Everything about this game is perfect and it's so far only in pre-alpha.  That should say a lot considering what a fan I am of the originals.  I was ready to be overly critical of this sequel but Stainless has gone right back to their roots with this game and it shows.  Currently only in Pre-Alpha, theres only access to 3 tracks and 6 cars.  But the original Carmageddon experience is still in tact with what is there.  Race to win, Kill to win, Destroy to win.  Win however you want to.  It's a free form racing game at it's finest.  By the time they add multiplayer, modding, and bump up the number of vehicles to 30 like the original (And they plan to) this game will be a solid game.  I love it now, but can't wait till it is finished.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Here's some gameplay (as of 11/04/2014);
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sDa_cKEBfK4

For those of you that don't know, Carmageddon is a long running series of violent racing videogames. Starting in 1997, it had two fantastic games and one hell of a flop which would delay it's return until today. The developer team is made up of hard core fans; where with Spyro they rebooted just for money and fame and it turned out to be horrible, Carmageddon is a game that has come from and developed it's roots.

So, understandably, classic gameplay is present. You have three goals; kill all the enemy players, kill all the pedestrians/cows/penguins or complete all the laps. It's really that simple. This can result in some hilarious gameplay (as seen in the video above and others on that channel) where pedestrians will splatter and the AI enemies will do ridiculous things to get in your way. All this while frantically getting through checkpoints results in complete madness and hilarity.

Concerning content and price, it's pretty much a personal opinion. You have to remember that when you buy this game, more will be added up until release late 2014. If you go on their site, you can have a look at all the cars they plan to include and there are several more concepts in the works along with planned DLC packs. The price of this game WILL go up around 30%, so it can be seen as an investment. As of 27/03/2014, you get six cars and four levels.

One of the game's key mechanics is the damage effects. It is similar to those of Next Car Game's; smash into something or someone and dents will appear with chunks flying off your vehicle. Wheels can be lost and tyres will even pop when put under too much strain, and on rare occurences your driver can be flung from their windscreen. All this, with a regenerative repair button which sucks your lost parts back from the terrain to your car. It is a pretty awesome feature that can only be seen to be truley appreciated.

Multiplayer will be one of the next things to arrive. Calm your horses.

So yes, I would recommend this game. But only if you have intentions of playing it in it's full release, otherwise it's a waste of money. Go get it. You know you want to.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Absolutely excellent already, with a lot of promise. The devs are very active on their forums at carmageddon.com and stream on Twitch for 2 hours every wednesday where they answer questions, respond to feedback and chat with the community on camera.

There is new content added all the time and it's incredibly open to modding with users already creating and releasing mods on the forums and expansive modding tools to be released. Steam Workshop support will be added for easy installation of mods.

It is in pre-alpha right now, so it is not optimized for performance yet but improves with every update. There is already a good amount of content, with the first version of multiplayer to be released next week. In addition to a lot of cars and levels that are already in, modded levels and cars from the first game ported by the community are also available.

It is an excellent throwback to Carmageddon 1 and 2 with amazing attention to detail and love and care put into it. The way the devs interact with the community every day is awesome.

Local Splitscreen is planned, just like online and local multiplayer.

Graphics, content and performance are nowhere near final, so if you can live with that I can't recommend it enough. If you are a fan of the originals (Carmageddon 1 and 2) or just like wrecking things, racing and humorous carnage, get it!
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Carmageddon Reincarnation is the fourth installment (in aspect to their developers - it's actually the third by Stainless Steel's standards) by Stainless Steel Ltd. Carmageddon is an open-sandbox style racer in the 90's controversial for it's over the top vehicular violence in which that it allows you to race through vast landscapes, demolish and crush other racers and smear the pedestrians by running over them watching their guts smeared on the pavement, grass and sidewalks. Lovely!

Carmageddon Reincarnation plays similarly to it's predecessors with the same amount of 'weight' to the cars being heavy and impactful on crashes but it retains it great sense of speed one of it's weaknesses remains from the inability to control the car. The game still does not focus on actual racing unless you play multiplayer.

It also has a great selection of cars that you can use to smash up and crush cars and power ups to fling them high into the air or turn them into tin cans!

Graphically the game features a detailed damage model governed by soft-body physics, making crashs a ton of fun to do and making you go out stylishly. Suffers mild FPS drops and maybe the old stutter at times if lots of cars are crashing.

Most of the problems however were solved with a recent patch and even offers multiplayer which is great. The career mode is challenging and a tad grindy but offers multiple locales and some oldies from the first game.

Oh! And they give you the previous Carmageddons, FOR FREE or for cheap as chips (less than 10 quid at most) (if you purchased during the alpha-access), so theres no reason not to buy this and run over some grannies!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a major improvement over the previous generations of Carmageddon. Yes, it is a beta version, there are going to be some problems. If you are a fan of the game series, it would be worth it just to be able to say that ‚ÄúYou were there.‚Äù True fans do not mind sitting on the bleeding edge. Deal with it, and try to have fun.

The game is still the same as before: high powered, obnoxious, as politically uncorrect as Jeremy Clarkson and Craig Charles after a few beers and some rather harsh words about each other's auntie. The music is still as wild as before, though much of it is dubstep. Though this is kind of hard to avoid now a days since the future is nothing but dubstep.

Game play: We still run over pedestrians, and slam other cars into walls or off ledges, etc. But one of the rather subtle changes that I noticed after a while is that it is a lot harder being a psychopath than one would think. There is more to it than getting all of the voices in your head to scream the same thing in chorus. Running over pedestrians is now much more work; sometimes it takes a couple of passes to kill one properly. Not to mention now it is near impossible to drive in a straight line over a corpse littered street without some limb or torso causing you to drift off to one side or the other. And after a few obese pedestrians flying over your hood, you will begin to question if perhaps you should go run a few more laps on a regular basis just in case you wind up on the other end of the chrome grille. As with previous generations of the game, the physics engine does a pretty good job of being fairly realistic, considering that we are driving around in a rather anti-social manner.

Graphics: I think that this is where this game really shines. The graphics are a major improvement over the older games where you had to train yourself to recognize which distant pixel you should aim for before you get near it, or what really that polygon is supposed to represent. The buildings are highly detailed, objects behave like they are actual objects. Several places I had to stop the car to see some of the jokes that were purposefully inserted into the game, and there are a lot of them.
But for the long time fan, you will also notice that a lot of the maps are more than just mere re-imagings of older layouts.

Bugs: Haven't seen anything unusual that would not be seen in any other game. Some prims still clip each other. And some game sprites make you wonder if they were fed nothing but raw meat, hate, and lead paint chips judging by their antics. One race I watched for five minutes straight Rusk jumping a ramp, crashing, recovering, and starting over at the same place on the ramp repeatedly before I decided that I needed the points more than being entertained.

reviewText:
This is a racing game where the word 'racing' isn't being taken to serious. This is a racing game where exploring with a car comes to it's rights. This is a racing game where it actually pays to crash someone else to steal their laps. This is Carmageddon: Re√Øncarnation.

Of course the ones who do know the word Carmageddon do immediatly think of running over people, which still counts here. The big difference between the earlier versions and this one is: the first Carma was very controversial with running over old people and made it very graphical. This one is still... graphical. But it is not the focus this time. This time it's simple and utter fun with vehicular chaos.

Running over peds* is still magnificent, don't get me wrong here, but the game truly comes in it's right when you play multiplayer (no peds included). Admitted some work still needs to be done but as soon as you get a full room, laughter (or irritation) is guaranteed!

Stainless did release this game a little to soon and surely it got quite the negative reviews when it was released because of the poor optimization but they are still working on it. In fact load times aren't tedious long anymore and framerates dramatically improved since its release date (different per pc configuration of course).

What is good about this game then you ask?

Well, open world racing not to be taken to serious is one thing for starters.
Car designs I still find very good; from the slow and deadly to the fast and dead one's and everything in between. Damage systems are very fun!
Graphics some people do find bad but Stainless did work with the tools they got/created; nothing seems out of place (check some older games with graphic enhancements" and you'll know what I mean).

And what about the bad things?

It could use a little more maps (but that's just me whining).
Optimization here and there (as stated above it is being worked on still).
The way multiplayer lobbies work definetly still needs some work although in-game multi nothing is wrong.

Would I recommend it? It is a game and games are created for your entertainment. Well it surely entertained me! And we need more online players!
I od undestand some hesitation when you see 'unoptimized' bu then at least give it a chance when it is on sale!

*Peds are very human like and live in secluded settlements away from humans. Some researchers mistakenly named them pedestrians when first discovered and finally shortened for peds. These "people" have in fact less brains then the average human and burst quite easily (very fun!). More researchers are required to see how these peds react to being hit by cars.
Also: researchers are being pit against eachother without the meddling of these petty creatures to show who is the best researcher!"

reviewText: Game brings back what's original was best known for. Smashing opponents' cars as well as dismembering peds is enormously enjoyable. Vehicles damage is modeled quite in detail and you may create some really interesting kinked and twisted sculptures of of your opponents' cars (and they, and the police especially can do the same with yours). Big variety of powerups (some really annoying though), greatly improved and interesting locations are another advantages of this title. New gameplay modes are playable but they don't deliver much fun (except Car Crusher and maybe Death Race). Current version runs smooth, crashes are occasional but they happen unfortunately. Hope there will be DLCs with Splatpack or Carmageddon II cars and some new locations.\nAll in all I give new Carmageddon 8 out of 10 and a recomendation.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this a couple of updates ago when it was still in alpha... had a lot of crashes (and not the kind you are supposed to have in this game), whenever i tried loading the city map my computer hung itself up completely, the performance was very bad on high settings, unplayable at max (i7-4770 3.4GHz, 8 GB RAM, GTX 760 OC@1240MHz).
The performance in the beta now is slightly better, had a CTD in my first race (appearently my nvidia driver crashed, never happened to me before...) but compared to the last alpha version it seems like a lot improved... i dont have much play time because i played a couple of short races and quit because of the technical problems so far...

But I still recommend this game to anyone who likes the old carmageddon games! it looks pretty good, it is fun, even with the technical problems it's worth buying for any fan. it is early access so you can help the devs now by supporting their work, report bugs, maybe throw in a couple of ideas... they take their time with updates but it's obvious that they are working on it. Plus you get the old carma games as a bonus!

But beware that this is just out of alpha and you will experience problems, this game is far from optimized and finished!

Update: After 2 CTDs in the first race the game stopped crashing. i'm on career level 5 now without problems, just some performance hickups and it's a lot of fun!

I glad that this is finally happening. The Alpha is looking good. It feels like the old Carma, but it is in HD, with new maps, new cars, etc.

It definitely would work more than a post-apocalyptic scenario that TDR had.

Hope my review can help.

Good luck guys!

reviewText:
I don't know if it's the nostalgia factor or simply the crunching of bones with my bumper. I played the original Carmageddon when it first came out and could never get enough of the feel good brutality of it all. Whether it be squishing a pedestrian from above or sending an electrical current through their soul, it's a beautifual game with an extraordinary storyline that makes you feel all mushy inside. I have tears rolling down my cheeks as well as my eyeballs whilst quietly reflecting on the magnificence of it all... I feel truly blessed.

Seriously though... I must have bought this at the the perfect time as far as updates go. I have played for over 10 hours and have not come across any glitches that have negatively affected the fun factor.

I have a GTX 760 GPU and it runs fantastic.
voteText: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I just got this game on the Winter Sale so I missed all the technical issues that people seemed to have been complaining after it was released.  I have a Geforce 970, i5 2500k and 8 gigs of Ram and the game runs flawlessly; however it has long load times for levels (and even after a level, when it's loading menus), and I have an SSD so that's pretty odd.

The game itself is almost exactly like the original Carmegeddon, basically a destruction derby race in the middle of crowded cities where you get points for running over pedestrians.  So that's fun.  The AI could use some tuning; particularly in later levels, opponents (particularly the police cars) seem to focus on you to the exclusion of others , which can make for a frustrating experience.  Add in that at least the early cars you have access to seem underpowered compared to the AI, in that they seem capable of pushing you around and into walls with impunity while if you try to do the same to them, they will apply their brakes until you come to a halt, or they peel themselves away from your bumper.

So, the game isn't quite the cathartic experience I would prefer.  Instead after the first few levels it becomes important to go around picking up power-ups (particularly, the opponent repulsificator, and the anvil launcher) to do in your enemies without having to spam the recover button.  It becomes more tactical, which I suppose is a good thing.

Still, I had fun with the game.  The developers are active so hopefully they will continue to tweak the gameplay.  If your the type of person who likes to murder people with automobiles you should pick it up.

reviewText:
I feel with the latest update to this game, we finally have the Carmageddon sequel we have been waiting for. I know a lot of people complain about the car handling, but from someone who has played Carmageddon since the originals, I know the handling has never been perfect. My only complaint right now is there seem to be too many ray type weapons over weapons that do awesome physical damage.

I also read about people having problems with frame rates and game not running well. I have never had issues with my computer. My graphics card is a GTX 970 and this game runs smooth no matter what I am doing.

If you are looking into this game and love the old Carmageddon's, I would recommend it. If you are tired of regular racing games and want some crazy action, I would recommend this. If your style of racing is Gran Tourismo and F1 Racing, give this a try still. :) And with Steam's easy refund policy, if it isn't your thing, there you go.
